number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												In early 1996 the original Resident Evil was released and PlayStation 1 players could play what would become one of the unquestioned kings of horror-survival games.  The games have evolved and change over the years and now the sixth installment of Resident Evil brings back the continued story of the terrible biological experiments conducted by the Umbrella corporation.The Good: This game had some of the least painful network I've ever used.  Simply invite a friend from your steam list and off you go!  The graphics for this game are also absolutely exceptional.  Only water looks a little off and even then it is not by much.  A movie done with this games engine would be easy to watch and still be immersed.The Bad:  Absolutely Phorking Every-Gord-Dammed-Thing Else!  Resident Evil 6 is the sad, discouraging, despicable end to a wonderful series that will leave a horrible taste in your mouth and keep you wondering how this series could have gone so wrong.  This game has no redeeming qualities other than some clean networking and graphics and, let's face it "good graphics" only mean anything for the first 1-2 years after release at best.  The frustrating and slow, maladroit player controls, the labyrinthian and discouragingly non-intuitive UI, the "thanks-for-that-one-captain-obvious" dialog from start to finish, the excruciating predictability, the painfully relentless stream of cliches and the unentertaining grind of fighting the basic monsters make this game much more of a chore than a game.  I was stunned when I started playing RE6, I thought to myself, "this MUST be a joke, this is SO BAD nobody could have possibly actually though that anyone would play this game and say to themselves 'hey, we've got a solid game here!' but no, it is actually this bad.  The engine for this games feels like your character is extremely dizzy and running through waist deep water, QTE's (which is a whole separate rant I will spare you) absolutely ruin any form of immersion the game could have had.  I am not kidding when I say that there are no redeeming qualities to this game.  The only way I was able to stomach the few hours I lost to this game had nothing to do with the game itself but rather the fact that I had a great co-op buddy to endure this game with.  We were like Tom Servo and Crow from Mystery Science Theater 3000 and made fun of each and every dissapointment this game threw at us.  Much like someone bleeding to death that is telling jokes to stay conscious, humor was the only way we made it to the end of one of the campaigns in this game.  For the love of all that is good and holy DO NOT BUY RESIDENT EVIL 6!  THIS IS A TERRIBLE GAME!  Care to read more about how unbearably bad this game is?  Read Jim Sterling's review on Destructoid, after reading what he had to say and after enduring (not playing or enjoying but enduring) this game for 14 LONG! hours I can honestly say his review is 100% spot on!  (http://www.destructoid.com/review-resident-evil-6-235326.phtml)The Funny:  If you are the kind of person who can laugh at horrible jokes AND if you have never played a Resident Evil game before then you will be able to laugh at how poorly the otherwise wonderful Resident Evil series will ends.  If I didn't like the series I'd laugh it off as the death of a fantastic series that was snuffed out just two years before it's 20th aniversary.  Since I did like the series however, I am dissapointed and angry that this tidal wave of frusteration is how Resident Evil goes out.  Imagine the worlds greatest pianist playing Beethoven's 9th symphony and right at the crescendo they stop playing, run over and slap you in the face, take a♥♥♥♥♥♥on your lap and then give you the finger as they run away screaming ... that's how it feels to like the Resident Evil series and then to have this game be released with the Resident Evil name undeservedly written across it's title screen.Summary: Seriousley fu(k QTEs, fu(k AAA titles using wonderful old series to turn a quick buck and fu(k who ever was responsible for this God-forsaken train wreck of a game.  If it had been a stand along game that we could all forget that would be one thing but it's not, it's a beloved 18 year old horror-thriller series!  It feels as if Brandon Sanderson replaced the end of the Wheel of Time with a picture of his nut sack (that's not an invitation Brandon, please don't do that and keep up the good work!).  I give Resident Evil 6 a 2 out of 10 and since I had a great co-op partner I give both of those points to us, not to Resident Evil 6, since we were the ones who made some tiny pittance of fun out of a game that offered not one iota of joy by itself.Summary: 2 out of 10

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game is legitimately great, it knows what it is and it nails that so well: a big, dumb, cinematic console shooter with a co-op lean.I do not know what occured in it post-release, with patches, tweaks, fixes, etc, but this game is hilarious and an absolute ball with someone else. Combat is very polished, the game offers a varried and highly satasfying selection of difficulties and there is a LOT of content on display here.I do enjoy classical Resident Evil, and this isn't it, this is a straight up corridor action game with a lot of co-op mechanics, good combat and a story that NEVER attempts to take itself seriously unlike the current landscape of overwrought "feels" titles.If you liked RE5, paticularly in co-op, and you feel like you'd want that but faster, flashier, smoother and even goofier, then check it out.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Not really sure what to say.. I don't normally write reviews. But I have been a fan of the resident evil series since day one. While this isn't exactly a bad game, it just seems to be missing something.. and it also happens to be the only game in the series that I have not finished. I completed just one of the campaigns and feel like the game just doesn't have anything else to offer. There just aren't a lot of "resident evil" moments to be had here..   I liked RE5.. and played through more than once.. I loved RE4.. and logged countless hours... I would still be playing if I hadn't lost the disc..   To me, this is the formula that they need to rediscover.

content:
Posted: January 8
												I liked getting this game on a steam sale for pretty cheap with all the DLC as well since I love the franchise but this isn't a Resident Evil/Biohazard game. It's just not. RE6 is more like Die Hard starring Leon, Chris, Wesker's demon spawn and Ada. I'd say it's more like Left 4 Dead but those characters are literally in the game. There's always some Burning Semi-Truck that is running you over as soon as you finish doing whatever it was that the last one broke. If you like action shooters and it's on sale then go for it. But if you are thinking survival horror where running to conserve ammo or like puzzles where the solution isn't literally right beside the problem then this may not be the mindless shooter for you.P.S. RE6/BH6 is a poor fps now with the a bunch of the same action and not enough horror or (challenging) puzzles.P.P.S I can't wait for the remake of Resident Evil 2/Biohazard 2 that is being completely reworked!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I imagine, when the game was being developed, some important person must have been walking around the studio yelling "MORE CALL OF DUTY!  I WANT SNOWMOBILE CHASES!  I WANT A MOTORCYCLE CHASE WITH A FRIGGIN HELICOPTER COMING AT THE PLAYERS!  THEN, I WANT A PART IN THE GAME WHERE PLAYERS FIGHT A T-REX, FROM A HANG GLIDER!"  And everyone had to listen to him (except for the hang glider part).  It's just absurd.  	The movement and hand-to-hand combat system is fun as hell, but players may find it difficult to use when the game constantly flashes to tedious cut scenes or forces your camera angle to look at some minuet detail going on in the background.  These interruptions or hiccups in gameplay happen far too often; it was as if the developers were concerned that players might not catch the small details they inserted, so they force you to look at them, every time.  This insecure tactic hurts replay value as many will get tired of being forced to look at the same cosmetic event over and over.  	You want enjoyment out of this game?  Grit your teeth, play through the storyline, and unlock 'The Mercenaries' mini-game.  The mini-game is the only way you'll get to utilize any good aspects of this action game, unhindered (except, obviously, by the time-limit given).  Because, face it, there is no survival horror aspect in a game with tanks crashing into Chinese castles, helicopter fights, snowmobiles chased by avalanches, train riding, bus riding, hummers chasing sports cars, and a nu metal-monster, with mechanical arm, monkey-leaping form heli to heli(lol).  There just isn't.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												The alternating story lines of game allow certain varities that other survival horror lack or in this case "dramatic horror" by capcom. If you like the horror aspect the storyline of leon will prove much of a horror aproach closest to past RE games , while Chris's is mostly centered around action and if you want a bit of both then theres Jakes campaign. The gameplay mechanics of this game will please some and annoy others, for example the annoying and atrocious camera locks in some points of the game is VERY annoying coupled with the constant studdering whenever your in combat or in a chase sequence is very frustrating to deal with due to the fact that it will get you killed in the most stupiest ways ever. In the end I had mixed feelings to this installment of RE6 lacking any spirit of the past RE games in actual horror or true puzzles but is instead filled with redicious cliches, another is there  not being  much of a high replay value as in the Re. games in post game content besides skill upgrades. So if you are in it for resident evil and capcom (crapcom) this is the game for you.

												This game... I cannot express what a dissapointment it is other than saying that it is a disgrace to the Resident Evil genre. This is not even close to all the other RE games. Different gameplay (worse), poor storyline, poor, gameplay, pathetic camera, controls etc. The game doesn't incorporate the puzzles like other RE games. It has a strict course you need to follow, extremely stupid scenes that happen to "spice things up". It is so dark that you cannot see anything most of the time and the "flashlight" doesn't help at all. One of the worst games I have ever played and I regreat paying for it. DO NOT BUY!!!I would give it 2 of 5, and only because it is a RE game. Otheriwise I would rate it as 1. I will play it only because the story may be relevant to future RE games (which will hopefully be better, a lot better).

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												EDIT:Through further research, I found out that the biggest reason people drive away from this game is because it doesn't follow the same genre aspect as the previous titles. The previous games in the series follow the survival horror genre, while both this and RE5 follow a more action/adventure road with horror aspects thrown into the mix, which lots of people didn't enjoy. Seein' as I haven't played any other Resident Evil titles, this wasn't as obvious to me.I may not be the fittest to write a review to this game. Reason is because I've played this and Resident Evil 5, and that's it. I know lots of people here have been around since RE4, and maybe even earlier than that! Eitherwho, this is my view of the game and I'm gonna explain what you should expect if you're interrested. I'm also gonna make some comparrisons towards RE5, and keep in mind that I've played through that game tens of hundrads of times(most damn literally) with the greatest of joy and I know how all of it's mechanics work. Somethin' else to keep in mind is that I'm more for the experience rather than nitpicking on some small details. ANYWAYS, LET'S GO!(I'll put a tl;dr at the end if you don't want to read this entire review)MODESThis game has several modes you can take on. Of course, there's the classical campaign, but it's divided into 4 different parts, each part is played by different characters. You can chose right of the bat which campaign to start with and which character to play, and durin' the gameplay, you will bump into the other campaign characters. How you play it and in which order is completely up to you. Somethin' else this game brings back is Mercenaries, the mode where endless hordes of zombies come and attack you, and your job is to fend em' off and gain points while keepin' the timer clockin'. There are more special modes such as Survivor, Onslaught and whatnot, but I haven't played those, mainly because they are DLC's that not many people own. Plus, I'm more of a solo guy, so that explains it.MECHANICSIf you've played Resident Evil 5, you will know what I'm talkin' aboot. The game is built around the combat techniques and loads of QTE's(which is a very bad thing for most, but not as much of a big deal for others, includin' me), and RE5 was no exception. To be exact, there were two buttons in RE5 specifically, one to "use" and pick up other objects, while the other one was for partner actions. Now these two buttons were used all the time as QTE's, where you had to press either one or both of them to survive. In this game however, they stepped it up quite a bit. By default, left mouse button does a simple melee attack, while right mouse button aims with the gun you're currently holdin'. Pressin' the left mouse button while aiming will then fire the gun. Space is used for sprint, as well as usin' some objects(jump over a gap, climb a ladder, etc. You will also perform these moves when already sprinting into em'). Regardin' QTE's, they are very situational and may cause severe rage inducing tendencies, so if you are easily affected by such, well, you were warned.There is also skills you can purchase, both for the campaign, mercenaries and the other modes, which are purchased with skill points, which you can get in pick ups, as well as earned when completin' mercenaries games. Some of the skills increase melee damage, firearm damage, more frequent specific ammo pick ups etc.Somethin' more to keep in mind immediatly is that you can walk around while aiming, which you couldn't do in RE5(You actually stood entirely still when aiming). One more thin' I wanna mention is that you can manually perform dodges and rolls whenever you want. For instance, if you press space bar while aiming, you will perform a quick duck. If you hold A and press space bar while aiming, you will perform a left barrel roll. Same goes for W, S and D. These are also set to the keys Z, X and C, however you can press them whenever without the need to aim in order to roll left 'n right or throw yourself on your back to avoid an attack. Also, you can perform some epic counter attacks(known as coup de grace) if you press the left mouse button just as an enemy attacks. This also applies to many actions in the game, makin' this game very fun to play!PC RELATED SETTINGS(how good the port is)I'm no stranger to stuff like this, cus' I wanna play PC games on my gaming rig rather than console ports, and I wanna be clear when I say that this game is most certianly(and luckily) NOT a console port! There are enough graphical settings you can change(textures, refresh rate, vsync, resolution etc. Pretty much everythin' you'd need), and everythin' in this game regardin' the mouse and keyboard controls can be changed(however there's no secondary controls). You can also enable a gamepad(however you'll need to do some editing in some game files to get the Playstation button prompts, cus' normally you get buttons like 1, 2, 3, 4 etc. Other settings such as your preferred position(camera left or right to the player), laser sight or reticle, laser sight color, camera position, FOV(both default and when aiming) and lots of other goodies are available.PROS+Great remappable controls(you don't even need to use some of the controls, such as Z to roll left, since you can use the method I explained earlier)+Characters from earlier Resident Evil games are playable+Mercenaries mode(No Mercy mercenaries are also available with L4D2 characters)+great PC port!+Satisfying combat+Overall optimization+quality of textures are great, however some elements could be improved.+Plenty of campaign difficulties, includin' "No Hope" that was added because many argued that "Professional" wasn't dificult enoughCONS-Situational QTE's which take some time gettin' used to(not to mention that some of em' are impossible to complete without dyin' by em' first)-A somewhat cheesy storyline+events(There are lots of parts of the story where somethin' happens that makes you go "How the hell did he do that?!" or "That's just impossible". A big action movie vibe if you ask me)-Playin' co-op will enable Steam's in-software microphone thingy, which has rather poor quality, not to mention a rather big delay(at least back when me and a friend played together, wahich was literally on day one when the game was out). This can fortunatly be disabled within Steam, so there's no need for tedious game file changin' to fix it-Somewhat lacking in gun customization, primarily because more focus in this subject went on to the skill system(more guns are found within the game, so no need to worry 'bout that)-There are lots of cutscenes, both short and long, that -could- ruin the immersion in gameplayNow, do I recommend this? I'm gonna say that I personally had loads of fun with this game! However, this is certianly not for everybody, and even the most dedicated of Resident Evil fans would dislike it. So wether I would recommend you to buy it or not is entirely up to you, but remember that the QTE's will haunt you...Thanks for reading my review!~Melee-Chan

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Junk.  (and my first really negative review - ever)If it's a horror story with environement you're into, find something else and if it's action - again, find something else.  This doesn't combine them decently and both sides are weak.  "Time sink" comes to mind on this thing with plenty of hunting around for ammo to fight.Without all the ammo issues it might be an entertaining action game but not how they chose to do it and we'll not go into the laughable "horror" side of this game.  The biggest horror you'll face is how you managed to waste the money to buy this thing.I seriously wonder at the ignorance of a game designer who enables an unlimited ammo mode but only *AFTER* players have beaten this game.  Players look to up their difficulty, not downgrade it for later play-throughs.  Bone-head dev stunt there.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Junk.  (and my first really negative review - ever)If it's a horror story with environement you're into, find something else and if it's action - again, find something else.  This doesn't combine them decently and both sides are weak.  "Time sink" comes to mind on this thing with plenty of hunting around for ammo to fight.Without all the ammo issues it might be an entertaining action game but not how they chose to do it and we'll not go into the laughable "horror" side of this game.  The biggest horror you'll face is how you managed to waste the money to buy this thing.I seriously wonder at the ignorance of a game designer who enables an unlimited ammo mode but only *AFTER* players have beaten this game.  Players look to up their difficulty, not downgrade it for later play-throughs.  Bone-head dev stunt there.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Pro:+ There's a co-op mode.+ Surprisingly playable with a controller.Con:- There're needlessly long cutscenes every few minutes in the game, which you cannot skip.- You can't even access the main menu without playing a 20 minutes long tutorial.- You can not pause the game. Never ever. You have a phone call? Restart from the last checkpoint and watch the cutscene again.- Ingame HUD popups (e.g. inventory, menu) have different keys for closing them. If you accidentally open one, you have to search for the correct key to close it and continue the game. While you're being attacked, of course.- You can't attack bodies that lay around. Not until they start attacking you after you walked past them.- You can't explore the maps, there's only one path from point A to point B that you must walk, and there's no chance to walk  up to any other door or corridor.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												I had many doubts going in. It was a complete♥♥♥♥♥♥show rating wise when it came out for consoles, and I made sure I avoided it. So when it popped in a steam sale recently, I thought what have I got to lose, and I have a PC that can handle it. And I'm very glad I did.The positives first:  RE6 is  a good looking game. If your machine can handle it, crank up the graphics settings. Rain glistens off the characters as it falls, hair and clothes rustle in the breeze, and of particular note, the enemies are truly vile and horrifically disgusting, and I mean that a high complement. The spider-like enemies in particular always made me lean back from my monitor whenever they showed up, from their creepy scamper to the thick hairs growing off their bodies.There's an over-arching story broken into 4 campaigns, with the occasional crossover with the other protagonists at certain points. The individual campaigns play very much like a greatest hits package of previous RE games styles. Leon’s campaign is like a retelling of RE4, from the cathedral setting down to the Ganado-like enemies. Chris's campaign is more like RE5, heavy on the action and broad daylight set pieces in a urban/military environments, and Jake's campaign is more like RE3 as him and Sherry are chased by the Nemesis equivalent UsterNakk (sp?). The last campaign of Ada Wong weaves its way through the previous 3 three explaining her presence in each, along with her own motivations. Each campaign has 5 chapters that take ~1 hour complete, so 5 one hour chapters per campaign x 4 campaigns is a pretty hefty 20hrs of action content. It’s all playable co-op too, and the AI holds its own. It also can't die, so you don't have to baby sit if you are playing solo (like I did). There’s certainly not a lack of things to take on. The story took lot of flack when it came out, but frankly, resident evils' plots have always been pretty ludicrous. At the end of the day, you are there primarily there to blow away zombies and all manner of disgusting bio-freaks, which the game serves up in droves. What probably threw people off is that the story doesn't unfold linearly and jumps all over the place as you complete each campaign. You can pick each campaign chapter and there are lists online of an order in which to play the chapters to get the story as is unfolds chronologically, but frankly i think that's unnecessary as it’s not that complex. It can suffer from pacing issues but you are thrown in some pretty large scale set pieces at least once per chapter so the slower parts are basically quiet before some zombie♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan. Plenty of difficulty levels depending on the level of masochistic pleasure you desire. Overall, lots of replay value.Once you learn the controls (an issue which I’ll touch upon later) You will realize they have made some much needed (and appreciated by me) changes to how the game plays. Characters are no longer tanks, turning laboriously left and right. There are standing dodges, back, forward and side rolls, and a first for me, laying prone is actually a useful and viable strategy (it recovers stamina very quickly). All the moves are very well animated too. Also, there is now a dedicated melee button, which is long overdue, and makes it easier when you run out of ammo and are surrounded. Its balanced by each melee attack consuming stamina, and when you use it all you have an exhaustion period during which you can't melee at all. The new additions truly shine in mercenaries mode, which arguably stole the show for me. The now standard score attack kill zombies for time mode is surprisingly addictive. the new melee and movement options really benefit the fast paced gameplay, and you will find yourself getting hype off of some John woo acrobatics that you engage in, pulling off a satisfying headshot, then physically countering an enemy trying to cheap shot you, and finishing them off  with a stylish quick shot. Very, very satisfying and just-one-more-round inducing (also I did them all solo, Co-op would be an even bigger blast as it does get hectic). Score an A rank or higher and you'll unlock a pretty funky alternate costume for that specific character, along with a remixed weapons loadout. Another benefit I didn't realize was that Capcom and valve did a PC exclusive left 4 dead 2 crossover with the characters of L4D2 appearing in mercenaries mode. Not only are the characters fully voiced, but their levels throw absolutely insane numbers of monsters at you at once. There are some multiplayer options, but these can easily be avoided, as the active online community is long dead and you can save a couple of bucks by not opting to purchase them with the rest of the game. Of course there is the other side of all this positivity. RE6's biggest issue is how poorly it conveys necessary information. The game tells you how to move and shoot, but that's about it. Nowhere, not even in an in game resource of some kind does it explain how to dodge, or other critical actions like quick shots and character specific quick shot combos. These is particularly baffling as several of the characters have character specific moves, like Jake's hand to hand combat and Leon/Helena's crowd control shooting maneuvers, which come in extremely handy. Fortunately there is an excellent ultimate survival guide on the steam forums which details all these things, but without that I doubt i would have stuck around for even a third of the game (which i'm sure many people didn't, which is a shame). Another valid complaint is that the default camera is much to close to the player. Makes for great screenshots, but also allows monsters to sneak up on you and get a cheap shot from behind in. The fix for this is adjusting a slider, but that option is obtusely buried in the game's title screen settings, Easily fixable, but again, i wouldn't know that unless I googled the issue. The last irritant i had was that the game suffers from the dreaded Bosses-that die-but-not-really syndrome. You fight and put down so mighty impressive creatures, only to quickly realize that you'll fight the same creature again in another similar 10 mins later, except slightly remixed (the second time in a confined space instead of an arena for example). It robs the encounters of any real weight, as you never feel like you accomplished anything, as they are back lickedy split minutes later with no sense of damage that they supposedly received.But overall, I was very pleasantly surprised by how fun the game is. The campaigns chapters’ each have a how-can-they-top-the-last-encounter.feel, and you are guaranteed some sort of final epic boss encounter for each one. I would run through them again with a friend who was willing, but I'm glad I at least finished them each solo. The real draw will be mercenaries mode.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												I regret buying this.  My initial assessment was that it seemed pretty good.  The gameplay quickly degrades however.  It seems like this game is trying to emulate games from the COD or Gears of War franchises.  This could be ok if it didn't seem like actual gameplay was an afterthought.  It's as if they designed these set pieces or scenarios and then thought about how to shovel in gameplay afterward.  The first realization of this was in the gun shop scene: WE ARE IN A GUN SHOP WHERE IS THE AMMO?!   I'd assume the owner wouldn't be so stingy because it's a zombie apocalypse, but perhaps I assume too much.Ok, then aftewards Leon and Helena are on a bus where a big fat zombie is holding up the front tires so they can't get away.  They have to survive other zombies' attacks, while trying to emtpy enough rounds into the big one's head through the front window.  Zombies come into the bus, they melee them, they shoot the bus lifter, rinse, repeat.  It takes too long to get enough ammo to do this.  I'm ok with making a game challenging via ammo crunch, but this just breaks the tension and gets BORING.  Not to mention our big uberbadass Leon has a fatigue gauge where he can't kick a zombie if it runs out.  When we're surrounded by very dumb NPCs (who don't shoot the ranged spitter zombies) and trying to survive by doing super badass moves (more on that later) it was very frustrating to have this happen.  Game to player: give zombies running bulldogs and sweet roundhouse kicks!  Player:  Ok sure!! Game:  Oh wait we gotta be like all realistic and like the other big blockbuster games, so nm hobble around.  Oh also player, you can't keep like a shovel or 2 by 4 these guys try to attack you with to attack them back.. cuz like, we wanna kinda also be like old arcade games.  We'll just keep the worst of both worlds to make it frustrating.  Player: Damn this kind of sucks I hope the next encounter doesn't suck like this.So that gets done and it gets to the cathedral.  This was like in Wolverine Origin when they get to the island.  The game is cruising along, not good, not bad, and then the wheels just fall right off.  First off, this church has security statues with laser guided crossbows.  I'm assuming it's some kind of facility b/c of what happened next... so why would they have an odd, inneffective security system of this style, instead of some kind of modern sentry turret, or ya know, a locked door.  So that part is also really dumb.  Then there's the boss fight where a zombie will pick up Leon and tentacle♥♥♥♥♥♥his face if you press buttons wrong.  This was the last straw for me.  I get that in games, especially horror games, your character will meet a grisly fate if you mess up.  The scene was just so gratuitously revolting.  It must have been included solely for a gross out, I guess.  Well I don't play games to be grossed out.  Again, shouldn't the gameplay be on the forefront of the designer's mind?  There was quickly a draught of ammo and melee did completely nothing to this boss while NPCs shot at nothing with their guns that apparently had infinite ammo.  Oh wait this boss also spews gas which turns people into zombies but Leon and Helena aren't affected, they can just stab each other in the heart with a syringe and then take herbs like mints and are fine.So in a comparative summary:Resident Evil 4 was 90 percent great and 10 percent manure (button mashing sequences and the block sliding puzzle should have been editted out on the re-release)Resident Evil 5 is a little more on the manure side but that's still far outweighted by the good parts of game,  It has button mashing, but during one, the main character punches a boulder out of the way because he's just so damn jacked.Resident Evil 6 starts off pretty good but quickly becomes a chore, but might appeal to those who value images of homesexual♥♥♥♥♥♥in a game over decent gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Don't let its title fool you: Resident Evil 6 is not a survival horror game, but action-shooter.If you seek to enjoy titles similar to Resident Evil 1 and Resident Evil 4, then, this game is not for you. Resident Evil 6 is more like a World War II game, more, or less.Cons/Pros of the title:Pros:+ Great character depth and realistic personalities (Piers Nivans, Helena Harper, etc).+ Four major campaigns (Leon's, Chris's, Jake's, and Ada's) with 5 chapters each.+ Multiple Protagonists (over 7) for you to play, across these 4 different campaigns.+ Partner system, like in Resident Evil 5, with the only difference that the partner in Resident Evil 6 has infinite ammo and infinite health if controlled by the AI. (Thankfully! No more notorious AI Partner deaths!)+ Huge variety of enemies and bosses - From the classic zombies to the J'avo. (J'avo are infected humans, similar to the Las Plagas from RE4 and can carry weapons and feature many mutations)+ Each of the 4 major campaign offers different atmosphere / theme:++ Leon's campaign has the dark classic theme - contains zombies, dark corridors and is closest to Resident Evil 1 and 2.++ Chris's campaign has the World-War-style acton shooting theme - the most "american" of all 4 campaigns, and is close to Resident Evil 5 in terms of action and shooting.++ Jake's campaign has the Tyrant theme. You are being chased by a Tyrant-type of monster like in Resident Evil 3.++ Ada's campaign... well, for this one... I leave this to you to see what it is all about.+ Character/Story crossovers - during the story you meet some of the other protagonists, controlled by others or the AI.+ Skill system, that allows you to influence various aspects of the gameplay.+ Different graphical UI styles for the inventory and menus. Each of the 4 campaigns will have different visual UI style, as if you are playing a completely different game.+ Herbs and ammo boxes are here like usual! Lets refresh our memory. 1 Green Herb + 1 Red Herb, what does it do? :)+ Melee combat moves / Extended combat system for certain characters.+ Dashing and running system.+ Excellent Dodge system. With proper timing, you can dodge almost any enemy/boss attack in the game, if done right. This allows you to leave the battleS unscratched!+ Each of the 7 protagonists have their signature weapons and moves which others cannot obtain/learn. Ada for example has her trademark weapon, the famous crossbow, when Sherry has her unique Stun Rod and Jake is skilled in the Martial Arts and can deliver great blows with his bare hands, etc.Cons:- Your weapons and firearms cannot be customized, upgraded or improved. The ability of upgrading your gun stats, from Resident Evil 2, 4 and 5, has been removed completely from Resident Evil 6. This means, with simple words, that, whatever weapons you may have, will stay the same forever. - Camera is your biggest enemy. Causes troubles at times, especially when you need it to stay on your character's back but it doesn't. Super annoying!- During cutscenes, the player's character can die. When a cutscene plays, your character will stay frozen solid, but the enemies will not. This means, if it happens there to be enemies nearby when a cutscene triggers, they can (and will) attack your character and kill him! And, no, it is not possible to defend your character from these hostile attacks, as you will have to wait for the entire cutscene to finish playing (!) and then for the camera to return back to its position over the character's shoulder (!) before you can resume control of your character. And if you see the Game Over screen after the cutscene, it means your character got killed and that you will have to start all over again... How shameful of Capcom's part to let a such oversight in a modern-day videogame like Resident Evil 6 to happen. Trully shameful. The Game Over screens right after cutscenes shows how poor job Capcom has done with Resident Evil 6.- Most cutscenes can be skipped, but there is a good amount of them that cannot be skipped at all when the appropriate button is pressed.- Way too many Quick Time Events. At least x10 times more QTEs than in Resident Evil 4.- The game is trying hard to impress the player by adopting a Hollywood-style gaming  experience, at the expense of the player's own joy and comfort. Too many explosions and destruction in the surroundings, (such as cars blowing off, etc), can get repetitive and boring... And the camera leaves your character's shoulder way too often...- AI is very stupid and poorly written. Enemies could come for you, pass by you, and then forget about you,- Your partner has "body mass" and thus, you cant walk through him. This often leads in him blocking your path, especially in narrow areas and corridors. The problem here is that, due to the stupidity of the AI, he wont realize that he is blocking you from passing through a door, and thus, he won't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about that. For example If you want to pass through a narrow door (narrow = wide enough for just only 1 person to pass through it) and it happens that your partner is standing in the middle of that narrow door, you wont be able to pass, well, at least not right away... So, if you are in the middle of a gunfight and you want to get past a door for cover from hostile fire, your AI partner may prevent you from doing so, and thus, increasing the risk of you dying or getting hurt, especially on the higher difficulties...- The Cover system (Cover = taking shelter behind obstacles such as fences, corners and walls to protect yourself from enemy fire) could have been better... You enter into Cover Mode even when you don't want it, all just because Capcom decided that it was very practical to have the button for the Take Cover to be merged with the button for Weapon Aiming! Yes, you read right: if you hold the Aim button to shoot at an enemy with your firearm, but your character position happens to be near a corner, a crate, a fence or an wall, you will, instead of aiming + shooting, go into Cover Mode even if this was not your intention... how frustating! Capcom, you screwed it...- The game's story spans 3 continents (America, Europe, Asia), but it lacks any depth. It could have been better.- Your partner, when he is controlled by the AI, will rarely use the dash ability unless it is scripted to do so. This can be a problem, especially if you are seeking to get good timing scores / planning to do a speedrun in  chapters that feature very long corridors and paths.- Graphics could have been better. The game allows you to visit many different places, such as cities, mountains, ships, etc, but the graphics in some of these places feel really outdated...- It is not a survival horror title, despite its name. It is an action shooter title. It seems that Capcom took Resident Evil 5 and added a tons more unecessary action to its successor, distancing Resident Evil 6 even further from the series's successful and memorable roots.- No costumes or extra weapons unlocked once you beat the game.Capcom has utterly failed all my expectations for this game. Story is poor, no gun upgrades besides using skills, etc... But, at least, it got some funny steam achievements. And as a true Resident Evil fan and an Achievement completionist, I cant help but play this game for at least 400 not-so-entertaining hours. But once all the 50 Single Player Mode achievements are unlocked, I am gonna uninstall the game. And I mean it. The game is having problems and it isnt really worth of taking disk space in your computer if what you seek is to enjoy and experience a true successor of Resident Evil 1 or Resident Evil 4... Lets pray that Capcom wont repeat the same mistakes with the upcoming Resident Evil 7 title. We can hope that the Resident Evil Revelations or the Resident Evil 4 will be used by Capcom as examples on how to make a true AAA Resident Evil game title... We can hope at least... After all, hope dies last.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												(Wish there was a nuetral opinon not thumbs up or down :/)Have you ever drove a bus over top of a land whale and then balanced it on a cliff then get hit by a semi somehow and fall about 60ft while at the same time shooting zombies laughing your♥♥♥♥♥off because this game is blowing your mind with how ridiculous it is? Then at the bottom the bus explodes but somehow you and your friend crawl out and the only injury is being slightly out of breath. Well in this game you can experience that. This is not really a true Resident Evil game. In fact its so far from it that I dont even know how to classify it. I guess it would be a Survival Action game? I dont know.This game tried to be different and did great with being different but failed at the most basic level of making an interesting game. Sure Resident Evil 5 wasnt really a "horror" game but at least it made an attempt, with this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥you have Leon ♥♥♥♥ing R'KOing zombies over chairs and♥♥♥♥♥♥ It so over the top and doesnt make any sense about 99% of the time. Operation Racoon City had a more coherent story than this game which is sad because it was a spin-off that is considered non-canon. This game is not really fun per-se but its funny if you're playing with a friend that hates it as much as you do. You and your friend can play through the campaigns and make fun of all the crazy cutscenes that dont make any sense. Im just gonna list some pros and cons becasue I cant even find words to describe my experience anymore.Pros- -Fantastic Optimization-Okay-ish controls-Will definetly make you laugh-"Good" Co-op experience-Best version of mercenaries out of any of the gameCons--Story is garbage-Everything is just so over the top-Each Campaign is very short (Which i guess makes sense but eh)-Some textures are very noticeably bad and out of place-Not fun solo-ZERO replay value-No weapon upgrades-No treasures-Lame puzzles-Never in danger-Always have ammo-Never enough healing items due to them all being ammoI guess if you can find this game on sale for like $10 or something (I got mine from Humble Bundle) Then its worth it if you have a friend to play with but if you're an experienced Resident Evil fan thats looking for more I'd say skip this one and pick up Revelations or maybe even the Zero remake

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												very entertaining, Well executed, nice graphics and a fun campaign mode. However, controlling the characters with the keyboard, could be a mess...Use a gamepad/joystick for Windows. Exactly what you expect from Resident Evil , I must say that I love this game. I love the addition of four stories instead of the usual one story with three difficulties. Like RE5, there is a co-op option, which I do take advantage of, since AI's are useless in every way aside from healing you. There is more to try to achieve with this game, unlike the others. You can track your unlocked files, achievements and game progress. Each campaign has an interlocked story, but they each have different overall skill usage. Leon's campaign is more defense, since you can stay safe in most all boss battles by just keeping distance of rolling on the ground. Jake's campaign is more melee, since there are parts of the game that you can only use Sherry's stun rod and Jake's hands to fight, they also don't give you a lot of ammo in this campaign. Chris is more firearm attacks, since they give you enemy after enemy that can't be taken down easily and they give you enough bullets that you'll have to shoot to make noise to keep room in your inventory. Ada's is mainly puzzles and quick thinking, since a few parts of the game are a race against time, and if you so much as run into a wall for too long of a second, you die. This was an excellent addition to the game, so it doesn't feel like the chapters and campaigns all run together. All over, this was a very great purchase. The game is a clean and easy install with no patches required for full function. The graphics are amazing. I have this on a Windows 7 x64 system .

												★ = Poor★★ = Fair★★★ = Good★★★★ = Nice★★★★★ = Awesome ✔Heard quite a lot of bad reviews for this game. Don't see why is it so bad. Is it because you can't kick noob players? Your Campaign story suddenly turn into a versus game? First of all, why are you even playing it with strangers? If you don't want to play it with strangers, why not disable the co-op option in the first place?Sudden unwanted Agent Hunt invasion? Why did you even enable Agent Hunt when you don't want it?I know Resident Evil changed a lot, it's not like what it used to be, it's becoming more of an action game. But I don't really care whether it's an action game or a horror survival game, I'm here for the storyline and I really like it a lot.I like how the loss of accuracy after aiming for too long or firing a shot.No weapon upgrades anymore meaning no more overpowered weapons.No more annoying cut scene QTEs.Four different Campaign with unique storyline which are linked to each other.Playable infected characters.Ability to perform melee attacks and dodges with free will.Ability to move around while aiming.For those who don't like it, I have to say this is not the game for you and I really feel sorry for you to have wasted your parent's money.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Resident Evil 6 is a very complex game. It took almost 100 hours for me to get use to controls. The game itself is very replayable, fits perfectly for people like me, but if you are the type who likes to complete the whole game in 15-20 hours, you will be bored quickly. In previous series I was disappointed about the fact, that you cannot punch nearby zombies. So far this is the only game in the series where you can initiate physical attacks without having to daze the enemy first. I only hate that every character has his own weapons, but even this can be fixed, if you know how ;)Mercenaries brought tons of fun to me. Bad thing is that extra skins for each character are terrible.I didn't expect any good game to come out since Left 4 Dead with good versus mode. But RE6 is another one like this. Too bad Capcom are too busy or lazy to fix some bugs like rapid fire from shotguns and sniper rifles which are used by some pubs. In private lobbies it's funny to play using melee only, like Chris vs. Wesker (reskined Jake). Me and my friend done it a couple of times.In conclusion I'd like to say that I got complete pack for the full price and I don't regret it. 10/10. Good job, Capcom.

number of helpful: 50 of 98 people (51%) found this review helpful21 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												There are a lot of games that I wouldn't recommend playing on their own, but would recommend playing with friends. Left 4 Dead is one of these games. Resident Evil 5 is one of these games. Dead Space 3 is one of these games. Even Daikatana, despite what many believe, is one of these games. You'll notice that there's a trend in these games, in that each one is worse than the last.You'll also notice that Resident Evil 6 is not on the list at all.Resident Evil 6 is a game that includes 4 campaigns, starring Leon, Chris, newcomer Jake, and the formerly secret Ada campaign. These campaigns total to around 30 hours in gameplay, with each of the first 3 campaigns being nearly as long as Resident Evil 5. You may think "Wow, what a bargain!", but you're missing one key component: almost none of it is worth playing. The game takes a severe quantity over quality stance, and even when the campaigns aren't directly overlapping (which is a feature, in which you might've been able to play with other people playing different campaigns in 4-player co-op at certain points if anybody was still around to actually play this game) you'll probably feel like you're just playing the same campaign over and over. Resident Evil 6 isn't a survival horror game, but it's not an action shooter either; it's just a third person shooter with really awful, gimped controls that are only worse when brought over to the PC. The only parts of the game that are even slightly redeemable are Leon's first chapter, which is about an hour long (some people will tell you that all of Leon's campaign is good, but those people are liars - all of Leon's personality and charm has been drained and given to Jake, instead) Jake's campaign, which is the only portion of the game that I would consider actually slightly worth playing at all, and the Mercenaries mode, which is as fun as ever. The story is a convoluted mess that puts literally anything in a series full of convoluted twists to shame, to the point that it makes Wesker suddenly returning with superpowers seem like a natural character development that was planned from the start. Resident Evil 6 is, as a whole, just an absolute mess. A disaster. A waste of time, effort, and money. It feels like Capcom just got together 1,000 people and said "hey, make a video game" and let them each try to decide what horror is, and while Jake's campaign has an extremely noticeable increase in interesting locations and mechanics, the game as a whole just feels like a mess of ideas that don't go together at all and overall leaves the game feeling bland and mass-produced, and it's just not worth it. Even if you do play with a friend it's barely worth it, since it's not even good enough to play for the sake of laughing at since after more than an hour or two of 3 of the 4 campaigns your soul will have been stripped of the concept of laughter. Ada's campaign is bafflingly not even built for co-op in a game that spends 25 hours reminding you that co-op exists, and if you do happen to drag some poor soul into the game with you they get stuck playing as "Agent", a character with no dialogue, no background, no cutscene presence, and no physical prescence - he can shoot enemies, and that's about the extent, since he can't open doors, solve puzzles, pull levers, or generally do anything except get carted through the levels by teleportation whenever Ada uses her grappling hook.I can't even begin to recommend this game to anyone. There are some games that I hate that I can understand other people liking, but I have yet to see any sort of defense of Resident Evil 6 that didn't absolutely baffle me. For $30, you could buy Resident Evil 6, but $30 also buys you a ton of bleach that you could drink and have a way better time.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2013
												Resident evil 6 is a very good third person shooter game. i can tell you its definitly not a generic shooter game. killing the enemies does not get boring very quickly and the levels are everything but forgetable unlike actual generic shooter games. the game of course does have its negative aspects like the most obvious one, its not a horror game . the lack of weapon costumisation, changing and upgrading can be very annoying sometimes. there arent much of boss battles like previous resident evil games. and the camera can be very klaustrophobic sometimes. but i PERSONNALY think the removage of the tank controlls is a god gift. the ability to melee, counter, dodge, walk whule aiming, dashing at any time is more then just helpfull.the amount of enemies is also very neat. there is a huge amount of differences in enemies from the normal classic zombies. tougher zombies bloodshots (wich are waay to easy to counter BTW) to the new kind of enemies like ganados wich appeared the first time in RE4 also known as j'avo and their very many different mutations. every different enemies needs a different way to kill it wich is like a minigame for each one.the story is a little luckluster. since its pretty much just some rich snob wants to F*ck ada.but the story can be ignored because its not getting shoved down your throw like other game wich i want name here. i dont like the inventory system of this game. i think RE4 & RE5 did a much better modern inventory. i really dont like the fact that you can have all weapons at once. not choose wich ones you want like older RE games.but yeah in overall. this game is not perfect and oh boy how it sucks for being a resident evil game. but its alot i mean ALOT of fun. with a very high replay value. i recommend it to everyone who likes TPS or atleast loves the resi characters.its not even close as good as RE6. but it IS better then RE5. good game. not perfect. but good

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												Resident Evil 6 is the latest intallment to the series. The first time I played RE6 I thought, wow, this game feels allot different then the other RE games, like the combat, camera angles, and story telling; Even though the game is different from the rest, that doesn't mean that the game is better; Change is not always a good thing.Combat: The devs wanted to make a game that was more fast pace, and more appealing to new players in RE6; But by doing that they took away so much of what made the games so great. Resident Evil 6 feels more like an action game then a survival game now. one of the reasons the other games are so great is because of the combat system, you really had to think about what you were doing, and you conserve lots of ammo, and strategize allot, about where to shoot them, and what zombies to kill. But in RE6 the combat is way to easy, you can go in, run and gun with no consequence's at all.Camera Angles: I can safely say that, the camera angles in RE6...SUCK! The angles of the camera is centered on the screen, and the guy is way too close to the screen; It is really heard to see around the guy. The only time you can really see good is if you ADS then the camera will center over the guys soldier, like the other resident evil games.Story Telling: In past games there were one story in the game, but in RE6 there are 4 story's! And all the story's feel like they were half♥♥♥♥♥d. The only good campaign was Leon's Story, all the other stories had some cool sequences, but with out any spoilers, Leon's Campaign had the most going for it.The Verdic: I did enjoy playing Leon's campaign but all the other campaigns felt extremely half♥♥♥♥♥d. The camera angles were extremely annoying in places, and the combat was way too fast paced. The only game mode that is really good with the combat system is the Mercenaries, especially the No Mercy Mercenaries.Well I just gave you my honest opinion about the game.I hope this review helpes you decide.This is Death Wish Signing off.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Ok so lets get the Elephant in the room out of the way...Alot of reviews have said `Well its not Resldent Evil really is it...`. Well that is utter tripe. It is a logical continuation of the RE  franchise.Sure it isn't classic Survival Horror but that has been done countless times in the series and things need to move on. I for one would not want another game stuck with the frankly horrid and awkward controls we have been saddled with since RE:1. People do not rotate on the spot, neither are they incabable of walking and shooting and it's about time that convention died a sad and lonely death.This is a good game and has plenty of old and new characters meeting across intersecting story lines. So far I have played Ada's campaign and had a blast. There are plenty of secrets to find, icky things to shoot and the odd classic `makes zero sense` puzzle thrown in.There is a ton of Co-op, Versus and Online action to be had across the various DLC packs and plenty of replay value. That is the pros out of the way, sadly there are a few cons you should be aware of:There are more Quicktime events than in the Tomb Raider reboot and that is really saying something. I personally HATE QTE's and just wish programmers would sod off putting them in games already. My percentage scores for Ada's campaign is tragically low due to the amount of times I died because I failed yet another QTE mini `game`. Games are fun, QTE mini games are not.I can handle dying because I played like an eejit and ran out of Ammo or walked into an obvious Ambush but failing to waggle the joystick, press X at a specific time then hit RT in the right order at the right speed is annoying beyond beleif.The Controls are way better than previous iterations and being able to run and shoot is a godsend. However  there are ALOT of contextual actions and sometimes things go a bit wonky and you end up running into an enemy rather than actually pulling off some awesome takedown.Other than those negatives this is definitely worth your time and money if you have any love for the RE series in particular or action games in General.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Long time RE fan here (RE1 on PSX )! It was very hard for me to hit the recommend button for this game, and there are basically only three reasons why I am recommending it. 1: It does offer a lot of content. This has four normal sized campaigns, even if some of them have a couple of interlapping scenes, it will offer you plenty of hours of playing.2: With a good co-op friend this game can be extremely fun. People give these modern RE's a hard time because of the less survival horror, or the fact that they are co-op, but I think co-op is actually one of the series biggests strenghts now. In a world with very few co-op games, this game is a fun time if you have some good friends to play it with. I highly recommend playing on the higher difficulties. 3: It's the Resident Evil universe. It's more of an already cool universe with enjoyable monsters and enjoyable characters. Yeah it's not perfect but it's still more RE. Now what do I not like about this game? The controls take awhile to get used to, I don't know why, but they just feel more awkward than even the older titles. I think pair that with the extremely tight corridors in some of the campaigns and it just makes it feel extremely sloppy. While the stories aren't bad, I felt there wasn't a good protagonist on the level of Wesker. I did like Chris's target for the first half, but although there was build up it did not end the way you would expect. Leon's story I felt had the most boring / easy monsters, as well as the least inspired easy boss fights. I feel like Chris's campaign was just better over all.Then you have some minor nit-picks on things that they took steps backwards from RE5. No DirectX10 support, no LAN support, and over all I'd say RE5 even looked better. The share system for swapping items is gone, and unless someone tells you picking the setting as the host doesn't actually change the other persons difficulty setting. I think what disappointed me the most is that RE5 was basically a better game in every way. The only thing RE6 had going for it was length, but length is not important when RE5 just has more replay value. I think because I enjoyed RE5 so much more as a co-op game I will always just feel RE6 was one of the biggest let downs in the series. Don't get me wrong I still enjoyed it enough to recommend it, but barely.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												Resident Evil 6 is the latest intallment to the series. The first time I played RE6 I thought, wow, this game feels allot different then the other RE games, like the combat, camera angles, and story telling; Even though the game is different from the rest, that doesn't mean that the game is better; Change is not always a good thing.Combat: The devs wanted to make a game that was more fast pace, and more appealing to new players in RE6; But by doing that they took away so much of what made the games so great. Resident Evil 6 feels more like an action game then a survival game now. one of the reasons the other games are so great is because of the combat system, you really had to think about what you were doing, and you conserve lots of ammo, and strategize allot, about where to shoot them, and what zombies to kill. But in RE6 the combat is way to easy, you can go in, run and gun with no consequence's at all.Camera Angles: I can safely say that, the camera angles in RE6...SUCK! The angles of the camera is centered on the screen, and the guy is way too close to the screen; It is really heard to see around the guy. The only time you can really see good is if you ADS then the camera will center over the guys soldier, like the other resident evil games.Story Telling: In past games there were one story in the game, but in RE6 there are 4 story's! And all the story's feel like they were half♥♥♥♥♥d. The only good campaign was Leon's Story, all the other stories had some cool sequences, but with out any spoilers, Leon's Campaign had the most going for it.The Verdic: I did enjoy playing Leon's campaign but all the other campaigns felt extremely half♥♥♥♥♥d. The camera angles were extremely annoying in places, and the combat was way too fast paced. The only game mode that is really good with the combat system is the Mercenaries, especially the No Mercy Mercenaries.Well I just gave you my honest opinion about the game.I hope this review helpes you decide.This is Death Wish Signing off.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2013
												Make no mistake, Resident Evil 6 is no longer a (survivor) horror game; it's a full blown action game with horror themes here and there. The story is rather poor (great characters interactions but overall the is full of cliches and most of the backstory is crammed into documents you get by shooting snake emblems) and the campaign itself is full of highs and lows. When it shines, it really does - you get great setpieces, boss fights, interesting over the top action sequences etc. But when it blows, man - it really blows: you will rage in frustration over instadeath QTEs, stupid design decisions, frustrating stealth sections, slow-walk sections (the whole beginning of Leon's campaign), camera control being taken away from you (while enemies can still move and hurt you), annoying vehicle sections... ugh, there's a lot of that.However, the combat system is fantastic... once you learn it, because Capcom forgot to include a proper tutorial to teach you how to play the game. But when you do get how to play - it's marvelous. It's the most technical and versatile third person shooter that has been released in years, topped only by Vanquish. Forget about boring pop and shoot cover shooters that flood the genre nowadays; this game is all about slides, dodges, counters, stunning enemies and performing melee combos. :D If you spend most of the game hidden behins a cover or standing in place and shooting enemies, you're playing the game wrong. :PAlso, Mercenaries is the best bonus mode ever. EVER. Very addicting and time consuming and at the same time, very satisfying, mostly because it focuses on the game's strengths (the combat system), while throwing away everything else (those highs and lows from the campaign design).The game is definietely worth checking out.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Resident Evil 6I know a lot of people are not playing this game anymore, a lot of people hated this game for not being the nostalgic resident evil feel, and I know that this is more action oriented than horror.  Nonetheless, this game is amazing in its own rights.  If this game was not titled Resident Evil, I know this game would have favorable reviews, but it is.  If you are looking for an action packed zombie feasted game, then maybe give this game a try.  Don't expect to be horrified by the fact that the previous installment (not 5) had a horror feel into it, but accept the game as what it is.  This game tried to be ambitious, and though it was ambitious, it didn't cater its fans.  It didn't respect the fact that Fans can think, fans can boycott, and they might go against Capcom and not buy any of their games.  Regardless, I very much liked the game.  I enjoyed its action filled gameplay, did not enjoy the quick time events to be honest. Almost each cutscene has it and its stupid, but the game was good. I had over 30 hours of gameplay and if you have someone to play with, and just want to have fun then it might be the game for you.  Remember, don't play this alone and play it through Split Screen, Lan or with someone over the net. It's much better and less frustrating that way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2013
												RE6 is a lot of fun. I was very pleasantly surprised how much I enjoyed playing through the game. After RE5 I was ready to write off the series, but this corrects the course (mostly) for the franchise. It's like a big dumb summer action movie that never gives you time to catch your breath. This is definitely a newer, faster-paced RE even with the clunky controls. There are parts that harken back to the old school actually scary RE games where I'm collecting keys, I'm solving puzzles and it made me sad for that fantastic style is all but extinct these days. Action games are a dime a dozen, but a good horror game is something special. However, I gotta say, there's just something really cool about getting into fist fights with huge mutant monsters. There's always something getting shot, punched, stabbed, burned, blown up or crushed. This game has a lot of 'that was just cool' moments. My favorite was when one of the monsters gets run over by a school bus. There's four separate intertwined campaigns that take over 20 hours to finish the first time. The game is highly replayable. The story was utter nonsense, of course, but it was fun re-playing events from different perspectives. There's also a horde mode where the L4D2 crew are all playable characters. That was fun to see them in newer, spiffier graphics up to their old tricks, kicking zombie♥♥♥♥♥ There's even a few special infected along for the ride. I heartily recommend RE6!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2013
												I played enough of this game to recommend it to you. There's everything to love and nothing to hate. If we consider the last trilogy, Resident Evil from 4 to 6 this is easily the best of them all, the culmination of the action Capcom offers. You can do all sort of new moves which are awesome, you can slide, dodge, land on your back and shoot from the ground (which can be done when enemies drop you too), you can fight in melee with combos or switching to a melee weapon. I really like the fluidity of the game and it's even more fun with a friend. The coop of this game is great, you are not helpless per sé, you can counter enemies' grapples, you can even "stand up" for yourself if you survive long enough in a down state, but, of course, it's a lot easier if there's a team mate helping you out but that may not be always possible due to tactics gone wrong or levels where you have to stay apart for some time.There is much to explore, some campaigns have more exploration than others, graphics are really good for my standards (which may be low since I don't really care) and it goes at 60 fps even if the benchmark told me it would go at 20-30. The campaigns are a great idea, different enemies, different characters, different playstyles and it's a hard game too! I play at Professional difficulty, invested 23 hours in the game right now and I'm something as halfway through (I'm doing chapter 3 with Chris now after doing 3 chapters with Jake and Leon). I really can't find anything wrong with this game, it gives me the challenge I seek, the adrenaline, the fear (the fear of dying but there are some jumps too), the gameplay is perfect as I see it, this was much more than I anticipated, I'll definitely play this multiple times.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Bought this as a means to play Co-op with a long distance friend. It feels like a radical departure from the previous installments (granted I only played 1 and 2) as early on there's moments of heavy artillery and gunfire just raining down along with armed zombie gunners?? The camera angles shift, there's wild explosions and everything feels like WTF? Also, the game heavily relies on animated cutscenes that feel like unecessary cutscenes that makeup a huge amount of game time.To say it simply: the gameplay is very awkward and cumbersome, which I guess it part of the franchise. Resident Evil has always been a clunky 3rd person adventure game that has frustrating game control. So that's the bad part.Now to sum up other bad parts that are actually really good. My advice: Play this game with a witty friend as it can be the funniest game experiences ever ala Myster Science Theatre 3000. Seriously, this game is so full of hilarious cliches that are worthy of commentary that it makes it a true gem in casual gameplay.The positive: It looks fantastic. I'm a huge Resident Evil fan but I guess I've missed several installments. This one looks incredible but suffers from the legacy of awkward gameplay. (You can run up to a zombie who's holding a fully automatic machine gun and proceed to kick him in the teeth)Currently, we've just finished the first Campaign.  Hopefully the other campaigns are as humorous and enjoyable

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Am a huge fan of RE franchise, and I simply don't understand why people hated this game. Yeah honestly game evolves from puzzle soving type of genre into a shooter game and later into an action one where u roll, do counterattacks and so on. Although it's a really big change overall, I found this game really enjoyable, if you are thinking about buying it, it is worth it the try, you can always refund anyway, but I don't think there will be a reason for doing so. The only thing you should consider is that it is a next shooter, not the original RE game, many old gamers tend to stop playing RE games just because of that, so, if u are the veteran RE type person, there is a chance that u won't like this game, although I liked this change and I love the game, that decision will be up to you. And shortly to the story, you've got 3 main campaign, including famous character such as Leon S. Kennedy or Chris Redfield, + one smaller campaign including Ada Wong. I like the plot and everything around it as always, and the thing that they actually met in the game is just briliant for me, I love it all the way. So yeah this game for me is 8-8.5/10, just because it's again a new genre which developers have jumped into, although I recomend this game, everybody who loves RE should play this, no matter if the person prefers Shooter game or the puzzle game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Recommend or not recommend - it’s not easy with this game.At a 7.50 sale-price, you get a lot of content for your money. But how about the quality of said content?The parts of the game which are fun to play, thrilling and exciting are “infiltrated” by parts which are not that much fun to play and can even feel like a chore. Sadly, some sections seem to exist solely to fill time, to give some variety or for narrative as their implementation (controls mostly) is mediocre at best.There are lots of quicktime-events - which is not bad per se - but some of them felt out of place, at times annoying.Obviously the creators had a big action-flick in mind, but the lack of execution in many parts make for an inconsistent experience.I think if you play this game with your expectations not too high - ideally in coop-mode - you might have some fun with RE6. If you’re looking for a polished, focused experience maybe not.Recommend for 7.50 or less.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2013
												Resident Evil is another franchise that to have any hope of enjoying now, you have to forget what it used to be. There is nothing for survival horror fans to enjoy here. Of the 4 campaigns, Leon and Ada try to pretend to be horror, but there's still too much action, and its pointless putting hidden key puzzles in completely linear maps. Leon also has to suffer countless unforgiving QTEs. Chris and Jake play like a standard 3rd person shooter, and therefore more enjoyable, if that's what you're in the mood for. Although they do have some frustrating running at the camera sections and dull turret sections. The story is okay but you need to play all campaigns to get the whole picture. One area I can't fault is value for money. It took me 24 hours to complete all campaigns, and only Ada's felt too short. Coop partner AI is vastly improved on RE5. My advice is to buy it on sale, wait until you're in the mood for a dumb shooter, then play Chris and Jake, and treat the rest as bonus content.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												While RE6 is definitely different from its predecessors, it is still a ride to hell. No Hope difficulty was a bit of a let down, for I was hoping for more of a Dark Souls type challenge, but its still a really fun game. Great Story, better voice acting than ANY of the previous titles in the franchise. With so many different ways to play, Leon, Helena, Chris, Piers, Jake, Sherry, and Ada, and each with similar yet different storys than intertwine together into a spiderweb-esque fashion (Kinda like the title screen I might add....thou im pretty sure I never saw a spider in the entire game.....strange, but something to look out for yourself to prove me wrong.), leave you never wanting to stop. I prefered playing the off characters to the main trio thou, they have different weapons...and not to spoil anything but Piers has a cool weapon you dont want to miss out on :P anyway, I would rate Resident Evil 6,  88/100

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2013
												Good, but not perfect.   In short, this is an experiment in the Resident Evil series with some experimental results. It offers some fun gameplay that takes RE to places that it's never been before.   Along with that, there are a few shortcomings that gnaw the overall experience.  If you're one of the pure traditional horror and tension over all things than you might want to look elseware.Is it better than RE5?  In my opinon, Yes, but I still like RE5.   Is it a groundbreaking horror-fest like the first several RE games?  No, not even close but that doesn’t mean that this is a terrible game.  Expect for your characters to be the most mobile that they have ever been before in an RE game. Even more mobile than in many 3rd person action games. You can run, roll, side roll, dodge, fight from the ground, evade while on the ground, engage in physical combat, and that's just a bit of it. This is a godsend from when I was playing RE2 back on the N64 in 2001. I always found myself cursing at the screen because of the bad camera angle or when Leon or Claire just couldn’t figure out how to use some low level martial arts against many enemies that had negative IQ's. Some people are complaining, but I enjoy many of the changes.  Not saying that there wasn’t times when I cursed at the screen while playing this game. Although most of those were due to the few camera angle and controls that tried to stick to the series. RE6 is much faster paced than previous RE's. This can be a big problem when a camera angle gets stuck and you can’t see your character or when your character jumps in the exact opposite direction that they were supposed to (the run button is the same as the leap over obstacle button). Thankfully this only happens a handful of times between otherwise good gameplay.The area where I had the most fun with this game is the same that I had with RE5.... The Mercenaries No Mercy.  Its basically a time attack horde mode where you get points for combos while you survive until the time runs out or until you kill 300 enemies. An impressive amount of said enemies can be on the screen at a time.   This teamed with online gameplay makes this game a worthwhile venture if you dont mind action (and a bit of WTF were they thinking) in your Resident Evil game.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
Complaining about Resident Evil 6 on it's Steam review page is like a black guy walking into a KKK meeting to complain about racism.


21:9 4/5k 
A Screenshot of Resident Evil 6 / Biohazard 6
By: GuyOnAChair




Fan boys hate any negative review of Resident Evil 6 and are easily upset with any further dead horse beating where as fans are torn if it's almost a decent action game or just a bad shooter in addition to being a jack of all trades and a master of none. That's before even getting into how it either fails to or doesn't do horror. I don't care what genre a Resident Evil title is or if it's even a "faithful" entry at the end of the day it just has to be a good game. To reiterate so long as it's good or at least so long as I have a good time I'm okay.My Steam review originally talked about the mechanics, story, controls and graphics but since people hate hearing about Resident Evil 6 so much lets talk about Pacman as it's a better survival horror game with great action. Pacman is less linear and has a far more cohesive albiet simple and less obtrusive story and if you really don't care about the narrative it can be skipped. The ghosts are more memorable and threatening than every enemy in RE6 combined too because they actually trap or kill you and have distinctive behaviors that test your limited limited resources.  (If you disagree with the last part you haven't played Pacman). In conclusion buy Pacman instead.

												Probably one of the most underrated RE games.  You have a bit ofeverything you could want in this one package.  Survival horror (Leon and Helana playthrough), to great action/shooter (Chris and Pierce).  You have so many stories and reasone to play through again, what is there not to like?  I am not an original RE player.  My first was RE-4 and I have loved each one since.  I am also not at all interested in team play, and these games still offer the best solo games out there.  Story, character development, and game play are absolutely still the best you will find on any game available.  Can't wait for RE-7!!!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												This game doesn't play like other third person shooters, and even less like previous Resident Evil games. Instead, it's one of the most rewarding action games out there.There's a reason why Mercenaries is unlocked from the start, because it's the best way to experience the huge variety of enemies and weapons. Make sure you practice parrying, because nearly every attack in the game can be countered. It's a fantastic risk/reward mechanic, since you're punished for doing it too early or too late, but when done right is the best way to take out most enemies, especially the bloodshots (skinless zombies).Even though Vanquish is still my favourite third-person shooter, Resident Evil 6 fixes my two problems with that game, which are the harsh punishment for using melee moves and the lack of extra content. Co-op is also implemented really well, but when playing in single-player your partner is never the burden they were in RE6. They have infinite ammo and health, and you don't have to worry about their inventory either. You're capable of holding plenty of weapons and ammo, so there's no need to use your partner to hold all the stuff you aren't using.To see how the game is meant to be played, with this LP: http://lparchive.org/Resident-Evil-6/The game's tutorial doesn't even scratch the surface of what you can do, so this is an essential read:https://www.pdf-archive.com/2012/10/11/resident-evil-6-advanced-controls-guide-ps3-1/
