number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Resident Evil 6 takes one step forward, and two steps back, in pretty much every aspect of its design, except perhaps graphics, as It's a nice enough looking game in that department. I can see how the series got to where it is at 6, after seeing the direction the series took going from 4 to 5, but I still can't believe it really happened. It really feels like the makers of the game ignored what fans of only 4, fans of only 5, and fans of both had to say. Instead, the game's creators seemed to  just says "Well, 5 was more action-packed than 4, so let's make 6 be even more action-packed than 6." They certainly made it more like an action film, but in my opinion, as a fan of both 4 and 5, this game took it too far.Here's the thing. I feel that RE5 was a terrible Resident Evil game...but a fantastic game! By that, I mean that while 4 made some big gameplay changes, I welcomed them with open arms and was still thoroughly creeped out and unnerved by 4's gloomy, creepy locations, music, and tone, with just the right amount of B-movie "camp" to give the game a nice bit of levity, and some really fun gameplay. 5 basically copy/pasted 4's gameplay with a few minor changes, but with one major gameplay change: co-op. Having someone to watch your back diminished 5's creepiness for me, and the tone just wasn't unsettling for me like it was with 4. The gameplay, however, was wonderful, and I spent hundreds of hours with 5 on PS3, both doing single player and co-op, both online and on the couch. So I find 5 to be wonderful as a game...but not as a Resident Evil game, because it departs too far for me from the tone and creepiness of the original games and 4. I love 5, though!Now 6...if you've played 5, it's like that, with the improvement that you can move while you aim your gun...except everything else in the game is one big, jumbled mess. You start by picking one of four campaigns. All the campaigns criss-cross over one another, which sounds cool, when in practice, I just ended up sighing as I realized a cutscene I'd already watched was about to come up again, and this happened frequently enough. You can skip them, but that just means a chunk of the plot of each campaign is all retreads of what you've already sat through before. You even have to fight almost every boss at least twice if you play through all the campaigns. RE4 and RE5 had a nice, linear story. Although the Ada stuff in 4 did a bit of what RE6 does, but 4 did it infinitely better, and it strengthened the plot for me. In 6, though, I just dreaded every chapter of the game.Dreading each chapter, not out of a sense of "oh noes! This is spooky!" but out of an "Ugh, I want this game to just end so I can finally put it behind me for good" is not what I want out of a game. I originally tried playing with someone on couch co-op in RE6 on PS3 but stopped when I got bored with it. I tried again with a different friend, online on PS3, and couldn't even get as far as I did on the prior attempt at the game. Finally, I managed to charge through the PC version, constantly wishing I was playing a different game; never considered which other game to play, but just knew I didn't want it to be RE6. See, that's the thing...during RE5, I was glad to see each next chapter, and I played through the game repeatedly because I enjoyed it. I've played through RE4 several times as well, and I've finished every attempt at a full playthrough that I've ever tried. I love those games!But RE6? Nope, I just wish it didn't even exist. Are there good moments? Storywise, I would say it was fairly creatively bankrupt and did not entertain me. Gameplay-wise, the J'avo, which are basically Las Plagas enemies, made for good fun, but that's just because it worked in 4 and 5. RE6 didn't have to do anything to make that good. They added zombies to Leon's campaign, and I thought they were dull and far less fun than other enemies in 4, 5, and 6. In the first chapter of Leon's campaign, I killed over 300 zombies, according to the end-of-mission report. This isn't Left 4 Dead, guys n' gals. Imagine getting 300 kills in one chapter of RE4 or RE5...that would be huge. Now imagine that it was the first chapter, instead of a late-game one. Rather than being spooky - and Leon's campaign is portrayed as the one that is supposed to be spooky - Leon's campaign is a slot through hordes of easily killable zombies that are less fun to fight than RE4's enemies, and your companion character, Helena, is dull and uninteresting.As for things I liked, I liked Sherry Birkin and Jake Muller's interactions, and Chris' missions had some pretty good gameplay. Oh, and Ada's crossbow is fantastic. Anything that feels like RE4 and RE5 is good, but then those games already mastered that. Also, you don't have to save your AI combat partners in single player, which is wonderful. Back to negatives...Chris' partner, Piers, was about as dull as Helena was for me, at least until Chris' final chapter. The overall narrative and the way each campaign criss-crossed into one another was just perplexing, boring, and made the plot harder to follow or care about, and the virus in this game is the biggest McGuffin BS thing I've seen in a good, long while. From what I can tell, it makes zombies, white goo people, smoke-shooter people, chrysalis people that each can turn into various things, Las Plagas people, and a FREAKING TRANSFORMER. I'm not kidding. If you play this game, just you wait. It's biological, but it's a friggin' Transformer. There's nothing this virus can't do, and it's absurd. Suspension of disbelief can only take one so far, and this virus goes over the line for me, then flies around the world two more times, passing the line again and again.Also, the co-op is "lop-sided in one campaign." In RE5, even though Sheva wasn't a big deal in the RE universe like Chris, players controlling her get plenty of kickass moments throughout the game. In RE6, on the other hand, one character pretty much sits out the final boss fight and is often needing to be rescued or helped in scripted events, while that character's partner gets special melee attacks that make the character the obvious choice to choose as your character.Do you like quick-time-events? Y'know, push a button or you die immediately? Those come up at unexpected moments, and if you're using a keyboard and mouse with the default controls, which are pretty much what most PC gamer using a keyboard and mouse would set the keys to, the key combinations can be pretty weird. You don't know a QTE is coming, then "Space + R" pops up on the screen. That's weird positioning, and you have one second or less to hit it, most of the time. I was not a fan of these and would have preferred something more natural for PC. On PS3, you have stuff like L1 + R1, and Square + X, which feel very natural and can be hit rapidly, even by me, and I'm a PC guy. =/I can't let this go: a major boss is a biological Transformer, which makes him go from human-sized to big as a house and back again to human-sized multiple times, and he transforms into different stuff each time. I still cringe when I see it...and since you repeat bosses, you'll see it again! Anyway, long story short, this game is not the sequel that RE5 should have had, and it's certainly not a step in the right direction to pleasing many RE4 fans, as it moves even further away from the formula that made RE4 so great.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												I have not finished every campaign yet. i currently only finished Leons. but i greatly enjoyed this game. The only thing i was particularly annoyed with in this game is that take time to kill every enemy in some parts you will inevetably waste ammo. for example after the part with the church in leons campaign you are brought to an underground research lab where you have to activate several switches in order to get to a door on the other side of the room which in turn required you to sometimes end your partner out on there own to activate things for you to cross. which in all honesty wasnt bad at all and was really fun. but what bothered me about it is the endless spawning C virus zombies. nothing special about them just your ordinary garden variety zombie that cant do anything unless you of course decide to walk to close or take in the scenery for too long. but still i didnt know that they would endlessly spawn so i sorta started popping heads hoping to clear the room. it didnt work so i had to restart the checkpoint to get my ammo back. some parts of the game you have to just quick shot a few times and then move or else you will get overwhelmed. which makes sense in any case. but to somone who does not know survival horror games it would be a big trap. even so it wasnt that bad at all and i managed to farm quite the ammount of skill points from it. other than that the game is excellent.

Having someone to watch your back diminished 5's creepiness for me, and the tone just wasn't unsettling for me like it was with 4. The gameplay, however, was wonderful, and I spent hundreds of hours with 5 on PS3, both doing single player and co-op, both online and on the couch. So I find 5 to be wonderful as a game...but not as a Resident Evil game, because it departs too far for me from the tone and creepiness of the original games and 4. I love 5, though!Now 6...if you've played 5, it's like that, with the improvement that you can move while you aim your gun...except everything else in the game is one big, jumbled mess. You start by picking one of four campaigns. All the campaigns criss-cross over one another, which sounds cool, when in practice, I just ended up sighing as I realized a cutscene I'd already watched was about to come up again, and this happened frequently enough. You can skip them, but that just means a chunk of the plot of each campaign is all retreads of what you've already sat through before. You even have to fight almost every boss at least twice if you play through all the campaigns. RE4 and RE5 had a nice, linear story. Although the Ada stuff in 4 did a bit of what RE6 does, but 4 did it infinitely better, and it strengthened the plot for me. In 6, though, I just dreaded every chapter of the game.Dreading each chapter, not out of a sense of "oh noes! This is spooky!" but out of an "Ugh, I want this game to just end so I can finally put it behind me for good" is not what I want out of a game. I originally tried playing with someone on couch co-op in RE6 on PS3 but stopped when I got bored with it. I tried again with a different friend, online on PS3, and couldn't even get as far as I did on the prior attempt at the game. Finally, I managed to charge through the PC version, constantly wishing I was playing a different game; never considered which other game to play, but just knew I didn't want it to be RE6. See, that's the thing...during RE5, I was glad to see each next chapter, and I played through the game repeatedly because I enjoyed it. I've played through RE4 several times as well, and I've finished every attempt at a full playthrough that I've ever tried. I love those games!But RE6? Nope, I just wish it didn't even exist. Are there good moments? Storywise, I would say it was fairly creatively bankrupt and did not entertain me. Gameplay-wise, the J'avo, which are basically Las Plagas enemies, made for good fun, but that's just because it worked in 4 and 5. RE6 didn't have to do anything to make that good. They added zombies to Leon's campaign, and I thought they were dull and far less fun than other enemies in 4, 5, and 6. In the first chapter of Leon's campaign, I killed over 300 zombies, according to the end-of-mission report. This isn't Left 4 Dead, guys n' gals. Imagine getting 300 kills in one chapter of RE4 or RE5...that would be huge. Now imagine that it was the first chapter, instead of a late-game one. Rather than being spooky - and Leon's campaign is portrayed as the one that is supposed to be spooky - Leon's campaign is a slot through hordes of easily killable zombies that are less fun to fight than RE4's enemies, and your companion character, Helena, is dull and uninteresting.As for things I liked, I liked Sherry Birkin and Jake Muller's interactions, and Chris' missions had some pretty good gameplay. Oh, and Ada's crossbow is fantastic. Anything that feels like RE4 and RE5 is good, but then those games already mastered that. Also, you don't have to save your AI combat partners in single player, which is wonderful. Back to negatives...Chris' partner, Piers, was about as dull as Helena was for me, at least until Chris' final chapter. The overall narrative and the way each campaign criss-crossed into one another was just perplexing, boring, and made the plot harder to follow or care about, and the virus in this game is the biggest McGuffin BS thing I've seen in a good, long while. From what I can tell, it makes zombies, white goo people, smoke-shooter people, chrysalis people that each can turn into various things, Las Plagas people, and a FREAKING TRANSFORMER. I'm not kidding. If you play this game, just you wait. It's biological, but it's a friggin' Transformer. There's nothing this virus can't do, and it's absurd. Suspension of disbelief can only take one so far, and this virus goes over the line for me, then flies around the world two more times, passing the line again and again.Also, the co-op is "lop-sided in one campaign." In RE5, even though Sheva wasn't a big deal in the RE universe like Chris, players controlling her get plenty of kickass moments throughout the game. In RE6, on the other hand, one character pretty much sits out the final boss fight and is often needing to be rescued or helped in scripted events, while that character's partner gets special melee attacks that make the character the obvious choice to choose as your character.Do you like quick-time-events? Y'know, push a button or you die immediately? Those come up at unexpected moments, and if you're using a keyboard and mouse with the default controls, which are pretty much what most PC gamer using a keyboard and mouse would set the keys to, the key combinations can be pretty weird. You don't know a QTE is coming, then "Space + R" pops up on the screen. That's weird positioning, and you have one second or less to hit it, most of the time. I was not a fan of these and would have preferred something more natural for PC. On PS3, you have stuff like L1 + R1, and Square + X, which feel very natural and can be hit rapidly, even by me, and I'm a PC guy. =/I can't let this go: a major boss is a biological Transformer, which makes him go from human-sized to big as a house and back again to human-sized multiple times, and he transforms into different stuff each time. I still cringe when I see it...and since you repeat bosses, you'll see it again! Anyway, long story short, this game is not the sequel that RE5 should have had, and it's certainly not a step in the right direction to pleasing many RE4 fans, as it moves even further away from the formula that made RE4 so great.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												On paper, this game sounds interesting.  Splitting the story into separate campaigns allows for each one to have a unique perspective and also create a natural boundary for your characters to develop.  There are also some added elements to the gameplay, like being able to melee freely with an added stamina system, the ability to move while you have your weapon drawn and move, aim and shoot while laying on your back.  I like the idea of being able to place your herbs into a quick-use container.  These additions give the game a lot of potential for taking the solid mechanics that were present in RE5 and building on them for a more varied experience.In practice, however, they completely botched this game.  The added mobility in combat is all but ruined by a terrible camera system, an awful inventory system, and sloppy animations.  There are moments in the game that are enjoyable and work well, but it never lasts long.  For every stretch of decent gameplay, you have a counterpart that is filled with frustration as the game teases you with control and then constantly takes it away from you.  There are numerous moments where your character will only move a few paces in between cutscenes, and far too often you are given very limited control where you can only walk slowly.  In these moments, you cannot open your inventory, you cannot run, you can not reload your weapon, you cannot change your weapon.  Even if you don't find the game awful, replaying the game or doing a speedrun would be very frustrating because of this.There are also incredibly lazy moments in the game where it feels like the developers were just adding filler to get each campaign to a certain length.  I really can't fathom that the game was tested for pacing or for player feedback, because it's littered with terrible decisions.It's a real head-scratcher, because there are decent moments in the game and the awful bits are randomly littered throughout.  It is another solid PC release for Capcom and i'm glad that Mercenaries has gotten better with each new release, but you wouldn't buy this just for the mercenaries mode.I bought this at a good sale price and still regret the decision.  If you've heard any criticism about the game before, it was most likely about the quick time events.  I absolutely hate QTEs and have to say that they were one of the smallest issues i had with the gameplay.  The rest of it really is that bad.If you enjoyed RE5 and are looking for improvements and more fun, stay away from this mess.If you love the classic RE titles and want strategy, stay away from this mess.If you want a dumb action-packed joy ride, stay away from this mess.If you want a competant shooter with decent level design and adequate story, stay away from this mess.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												I’d heard this game was bad, and having played the demo I decided to skip this. But then the years went on, and both critics and game developers popped their head out to say “Resident Evil 6 wasn’t that bad!”. Could there be something interesting here after all? No. No there isn’t.Maybe it’s a matter of preference? The way games like Resident Evil Revelations 2 or The Evil Within are paced is like a rollercoaster. You have long stretches of buildup and tension before all hell breaks loose. They both do a great job at it. Neither are particularly effective as horror games, but as action games I love them. Resident Evil 6 on the other hand is more like being strapped to a rocket. There’s some anticipation at the start, but then it’s non-stop action with set pieces upon set pieces with maybe 5 seconds of breathing room between them. I only played the first chapter of Leon’s story, and I apparently killed 228 enemies during that time. That’s the kinds of numbers you’d expect out of late game Doom 2 or Serious Sam.So all pretense of it being horror is out the window, and there’s minimal exploration and the pacing is nonexistent. This puts more strain on the combat mechanics. They better be good if it’s the only thing you’ll be doing. Unfortunately they tossed out the mechanics used in Resident Evil 4 and 5 and tried to come up with new ones. I can appreciate the thought. But what they have here is simply worse. Your guns and enemies somehow both feel weak and flimsy, yet they take more hits to kill than I’d like. When you shoot enemies with a shotgun, there’s no difference in reaction from when you shoot them with a gun. It feels like an underdeveloped system that was rushed out the door. This is especially true of tougher enemies. In the parts of the game I played there were higher evolved zombies that took loads of bullets to take down, and there were big fat ones that took the rest of my inventory to kill. None of them were intimidating or exciting to fight. All they did was add tedium because their health meant the action set piece would go on for longer than it already was. I didn’t enjoy playing Resident Evil 6 at all. The story starts in a laughable manner, and it doesn’t get much better after that. In fact, almost nothing happened in the 2 hours I played, as characters insisted the story would start once I reached a cathedral. But on the way there I had to go through 9 action set pieces, one more tedious than the other. On every level from characterization, pacing, tension, the feel of the weapons, the enemy designs, and the way environments were designed and lit was worse than it has ever been in the series. I’m actually glad I decided to play it properly, because now I can finally write it off completely as garbage. If you like this for some reason, fine, I have nothing against that. But I can’t understand at all what the appeal is. This isn’t mediocre, it’s absolutely horrible.

content:
Posted: January 17
												There are already plenty of brilliant reviews for this game. I just want to add a very simple "thumbs DOWN" and recommendation to AVOID here as well. Even as a huge fan of modern RESIDENT EVIL (4 and 5 especially), I could not make it through this pathetic effort. Everything has regressed, from the clunky controls and mechanics, to the story ("Uh... kill this new wave of things!?"). Bored to tears. Even the graphics are somehow lackluster (textures, environment, lighting). CAPCOM deserves shame and embarassment for this abomination. We know they can produce quality games. There is no excuse for this. My rating for RESIDENT EVIL 6: 4 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17
												Awkward control mechanics and terrible camera. Extremely unintuitive UI and inventory system, probably the worst of any game I've seen.  Unable to hotkey weapon select, you have to manually scroll trhough 10 weapons just to select a specific weapon.  Annoying QTE's everywhere.  Unnecessary screen shaking and events that make you lose control, designed to create tension and a sense of panic but actually just annoy the player.  Terrible game design decisions EVERYWHERE (e.g. you have to hold 'DOWN' to run away from something, then suddenly the camera flips for the sake of looking cool and hollywood, so now you have to press 'UP' but since you were already holding 'DOWN', you run right back into the thing you were running away from).  Artificially extending game length by creating 4 campaigns which are more or less the same thing.  The list goes on and on.As for the story and overall atmosphere, they tried to go "hollywood action flick" with this one--there is absolutely ZERO sense of horror.  The worst game of the series and perhaps one of the worst games of all time.  Googled the lead designer of this game and it looks like he never worked on another game after this one, thank god for that.  Matter of fact, every game designer that worked on this game should do the world a favor and quit the video game industry.The only decent thing about this game is the co-op, and maybe Ada Wong's azz when you crawl through vents.  Everything else is trash.  I'm struggling to force myself to complete this game for the sake of completing every RE game and obtaining and reading the intel files.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2013
												It's a game I can certainly get into once you get past the motion sickness and shakiness of the controls.. If you can. I actually just played it again and couldn't stomach it. That's why I'm rewriting this. I enjoyed the first couple campaigns but now that I'm on Jake and Sherries there's way too many boss battles and way too many enemies in a row. It's non-sense to call it Resident Evil anymore at that point. And the gameplay for that campaign and Chris' campaign are just not fun for the most part. I find myself getting way too mad at the controls, or lack there of, when you get bombarded with enemies/bosses. I still really enjoy Leons/Helena and Ada's campaign though. They're both compelling stories and the hoards only get uncontrollable in a few spots while still being able to stomach those moments to get to the next juicy part of it's story. They should've saved the devolopement money for RE 7 though from Sherries/Jakes, and Chris'/Piers campaigns. They aren't well thought out from an RE standpoint and I think they did more harm than good for the game/franchise itself.

												This game is beautiful, suspenseful and amazing. I have watched my mom play resident evil on nintendo as a child and cannot believe how far capcom has come (I was  born in 1994). I hate/love/fear/cannot wait for the next second while playing Resident evil 6.  This game is a favor to us gamers and horror lovers. Some may hate this game but i have only played 1 hr and wish i could donate extra to the devs. No other games can instil feelings into you like this games. This isnt a game but more of a experience you can participate in or not. A good one at that.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Got the game as a gift to play with my friend and from the special sell. The game is special in it's own way. This game is a mix, it good yet not good yet good again.Also don't questions the logic in this game.I enjoy the game even though it has flaws. Since I never play the other game I felt really confused at first as to who was who and what role they had in the universe. If you want to have a compleate collection go for it...and try and get it on special sell. I do enjoy the 2 player.This game is long to me and that cool but I had to take breaks. I thought only play as Leon and hi partner. After you beat his level you can play the other characters and see there side of the story.I have only play a bit of the orignal first Resident Evil game and a bit of Resident Evil Revelations. There a lot of nice maps and detail to things. Cutceans camera could be a bit more fluid and less choppy on transitions movment fad in or out to black. A cutscines will happen all a sudden where you walk a few distence then it cuts to a cutcanes I guess it to load the scenes instead of right after another scnese had already load but I notice this in other game I have played. The game is just weirdness in it own I guess. Menu option screen to just edit setting is  bit of a chore since your figuring out what the icon are even with a small discription. Control feel clunky sometime even though I adjusted the mouse sensitivity but don't feel improvment, this can be ignored because after a while you get used to it. Though would like to try with a game controler one day. The gun system feels similuer to Metal Gear 2 shooting style (and maybe there other games but Metal Gear is one I like and notice) but I felt they done it better or calibrated it better in Metal Gear. Some of the action seem redundent like "open the door fence that has a bar, I can simply reach my arm over the metal bars and lift the metal wedge. nothing stoping me from doing that."  "Oh no, I can't climb over this desk it block by a small box and junk, yet in real life I can climb over a desk to not set off the sercurity gate alarm detector." I could go on but yeah.I feel it like a crazy action movie I'm watching. The cars or truck that just come out of knowhere and I'm like "HOW THE HECK DO YOU SURVIVE THAT?" Even in video game logic. Maybe if the cheography sett up was done better it could be more belivabile like in some movies. Though animation is still great just feel like some of the film editing fad in to out could be a bit better.It's a decent game even though it might have flaws. From somebody like me who has not really play the other Resident Evil game and can say from a neutral point is that the game is decent for what it is atleast for me.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												I really enjoy this game. Honestly for RE going action, it really doesn't bother me that much. Even though I too like the classics and would love another classic style RE, I have come to terms with accepting this one. Especially since this game does kinda take it back to the roots a bit at least with the story (by that I mean using multiple characters to complete the story mode to it's fullest understanding) and overall it's still a fun game, even if it's not the RE that you want it to be.Graphics are really nice looking (while having some muddy textures here and there not enough to ruin the experience), co-op is fun, though on PC there is a bit of a trick to getting it to work correctly, and overall just a really enjoyable game, at least to me. I platinumed this game on the PS3 and loved every minute playing the game I decided to get it on PC.One problem I will note about this version of the game other than the co-op trick is tha this port for some reason this game uses quite a bit of CPU power. It will run fine on a quad-core setup but recording might be a different matter depending how taxing your recording software is. I would recommend a higher core CPU (AMD) or a high cache CPU (Intel) to run and record this game at 60fps, since this is a VERY CPU heavy game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												The first thing you should do when considering this game as a purchase, is ignore a lot of publisher reviews, such as Metacritic, IGN, Gamespot etc. After logging 4 hours into the game, I have to ask, why all the hate on this game? Granted that RE6 took a huge turn in comparison of each Resident evil game prior to this one, I still marvel at the gameplay of this installment. In RE6 you get 4 different campaigns, all supporting both local co-op and online co-op, so instantly there's a plus if you have any friends or family who want to play with you. Also, the game isn't the most graphically demanding game on the market, it's actually optimized surprisingly well. Probably my biggest problem though is that it takes away a lot of exploration from the game. On the majority of all chapters, you're limited to a rather linear path with next to no diversions or detour routes. While this wasn't exactly game breaking, it did take away a little bit of the experience. This being said, the atmosphere is built beautifully. With the soundtrack and sfx to set the mood, it's hard not to get immersed in the experience. In addition, RE6 takes a lot of elements from the installment that came before, there's a lot more action in RE6 than you would expect. Although the horror isn't quite there anymore, for anyone who loves zombies, anyone who loved RE5, I could not recommend this game any more.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Very hard to find something positive to say about this one. Even for a console game it lacks gameplay and immersion.It does bring back a certain sense of nostalgia for when games were far more limited back in the old days of games arcades but this just lacks basic game play.  Half the game is simply, press V or press R or mash a couple of buttons really fast.  The controls are often a matter of trial an error breaking from the game and story while you work out what buttons it wants you to press.  Very little challenge and worse yet a console field of view with your character often taking up so much of the screen real eastate that its hard to see the action going on literally in front of you.  It was cheap on sale so I thought what happened to this series.  Now I see it died and should be left to rest in peace.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												While I've never heard of Resident Evil, I'm really smitten with the entire biohazard series, particularly this latest installment that balances romantic mood lighting, coy glances, full on tentacle♥♥♥♥♥♥ and tantalizing homoeroticism between Piers and Chris Redfield. If you liked the end of Titanic you'll greatly enjoy the tragic homage death scene of Piers while Chris Redfield holds him in his arms and slowly must learn to let go. The audience is given a real sense of tension when playing other character's campaigns. Slowly, but surely, the audience discovers that this game is an allegory for two young (albeit suspiciously attractive) homosexual lovers (Piers and Chris) and the other campaigns are merely metaphorical representations of the tremendously frustrating challenge of coming to terms with ones sexuality while in a world where it would seem utterly impossible to cling to waist-level or below cover. However, they realize that much like standing on top of aforementioned cover, they simply can't avoid who they are, and I tell you the ending is sadder than a  John Greene novel.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I wanted to jump into Resident Evil 6 and castrate it for what it's become, but after a short time playing it I realized that if you accept that this is what Resident Evil is now; a third person shoot em up, then it's astonishingly good. The game mechanics are absolutely solid and the action is some of the most insane that I've experienced outside of spectacle fighters like God of War and Devil May Cry. The storyline has recovered surprisingly well after the death of Wesker in 5 and the games are starting to show signs of a future world-wide apocalypse. I would definitely recommend this to new players of the series and ask that older fans such as myself attempt to accept it for what it is. Would I prefer Capcom to go back to their roots? Absolutely. However in their minds that isn't financially viable and even after Revelations it's a safe bet to assume 7 will be as crazy, if not more so than 6. The metacritic is quite fair on this one, as I rate it...7/10

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Unfournatelly the horror of the Resident evil series is dead and gone. After Re3 the series turn to a more action based gameplay with keep the player interacted with QTE's and other prompts like that. Resident Evil 6 does just that, and does it well. The game have a kinda buggy cam the can ♥♥♥♥ you up when sprinting but when you get into some of the game modes such as Mercinaries and it's no mercy counter part you get a massvie joy-gasm of fun and death. The campaign still tries to keep the horror idea with Leon's and Ada's but after years of the same zombie jump-scare it's almost impossble to be afriad of something like that again. Chris's campaign turns in to a hardcore shooter more in the vains of a CoD or GoW game and delivers the action instantally. Jake's will not be mention due to personal disgust for it but it's supossed to be based more about RE3 with Ustanak as Nemesis. In a short summary I give this game a 7/10. It has it's flaws like a lot of other games but it's still enjoyable with friends.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												I love Resident Evil. Pure honesty even taking the name away this is a clunky mess. Graphically it looks decent.  I do not recommend this game as even a fan unless you catch it for 6 bucks. I will explain why I feel this way.The game is unbalanced far as enemies go....headshots ummm like 3 to 7 so being rewarded for conserving ammo by stockpiling it by being accurate does nothing for you. It doesnt matter anyways because theres tons of ammo. You will die due to cheap deaths. I can literally knock an enemy down with melee and stomp its head for a much easier time. Why have guns in the game just use you're foot.The action mechanics are cool and very John Woo movie like...But they in my opinion are for show more than they are helpful.I will say they add very light and I mean light puzzle mechanics to the game. The levels are actually pretty cool and especially in Leons chapter...but the problem is with limited interaction with the background theres no real reason to even explore. Not saying there isnt typical notes and journals to read they are just there for filler only. Having played Resident Evil Revelations 2 which thumps this game even in its episodic nature its far superior.There is no survival horror here. Theres no conserving ammo health or anything else.You do get skill point drops in the shape of pawns and statues that drop to use for new skills like better accuracy and so on.If Leon Ada and Chris were'nt in the game it could be a very generic action game.Not to say that the action is dull its very action oriented...to the QTE events in the opening of Leons chapter to the scripted areas of the story.This felt like an off the rails house of the dead game.You will either like it or you won't theres really no middle ground but do not expect anything even close to Resident Evil.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												"QTE is my favorite part of the game", said no one ever!  Spoiler alert, this game features excessive amounts of QTE. Interspersed lightly among the button mashing is the potential for a good game.  But that potential is sadly never realized in this pseudo Left for dead resident evil hybrid.  Most of the sub bosses share a striking resemblance to Left 4 dead special creatures. There are also constant interruptions to game play and repetitive boss fights which further add to an already frustrating and disappointing experience! There was potential for something great here and it was squandered! Hopefully the devs pull their heads out of their asses and get it right next time...

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												JUST AWFUL.prosNOTHINGcons- settings UI. there is no texts but icons. so u must put on cursol to see what these icons are for.- camera. no slider to adjust FOV though its narrow. so u will get motion sickness in 1st ten minutes.- head bobbing. of course u can NEVER turn it off. surely u will puke after some hours like zombies.- NOT free mouse look. u will be limited sometimes even to watch ur back. - quick time events. even when u must just run, it demands QTE with stupid unreasonable keys. - unskippable cut scenes. if u died in QTE, u MUST see the same movie repeatedly until succeed.these are my 1st 10minutes playing review.but only within 10minutes, this game showed these fatal cons.and i must say about the 1st zombies battle was awful too.u will be surrounded by about 10 zombies in the night street filled with abandoned cars.but there is no enough lights. only u can do is to increase brightness with settings.so u must struggle in the darkness against zombies with annyoing backlights from carsthese shi-t backlighs never light up ur battlefield enough though idk why, they just blind ur eyes.maybe it means by the game director, "have fun my battle design in the ♥♥♥♥ing dark place, nerds".so i STOPPED playing this game after 10 minutes from start.and 1 more fun thing to tell u, this game does NOT have the button to quit.only the text appears in the title screen, "press any key to start, blah"so u MUST press alt + F4 to escape from this♥♥♥♥♥♥game's hell,but even these keys are recognized as "hitting keys" to start by this stupid client.of course ESC key NEVER works too in the title screen.i wanna give 100 thumbdowns for this game.i noticed now why this game was bundled in my Nvidia video card.if u expect the fun like Left 4 Dead for this game,u will be betrayed and depressed like a zombie soon.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2013
												Game is decent, although it seems there are less games open for RE6 than there are for RE5, so I have to play solo most of the time (although I was playing in the morning, not evening yet) Campaign can be freely accessed so it can be confusing, recommended to play it with a "guide" of chapters that player should do before the others (not just from top to left, but certain chapters with certain characters to keep chronology, and game doesn't indicate that) Extra modes like merceneries are fun, game feels different than RE5 and as always requires some learning of controlls. Playing as monster in random players compaign is good idea, but hardly any chance for the monsters to do anything in my opinion. All in all 8 of 10 and a recommendation to all RE fans. The franchise is still interesting for me :)

												"QTE is my favorite part of the game", said no one ever!  Spoiler alert, this game features excessive amounts of QTE. Interspersed lightly among the button mashing is the potential for a good game.  But that potential is sadly never realized in this pseudo Left for dead resident evil hybrid. There was potential for something great here and it was squandered! Hopefully the devs pull their heads out of their asses and get it right next time...

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26
												First time I've done a review and after having fun with the two Revelations games and RE5, I've found RE6 to be extremely unintiutive and frustrating. Despite the fact the game allows for movement whilst shooting (which RE5 didn't) the controls and entry into the game are just plain unclear. Several of the quick time events are downright horrible and require instant reaction, which you won't have the first time.The inventory system is also a mess in that you have to go through a whole bunch of keys and combinations to do the most basic things. Even just using a First Aid spray I just found out is stupidly implemented in that it counts as a grenade and has to be used as one without zero information or useability from the inventory screen. It's just a clunky mess. It might get better but if you're coming from RE5 or a Revelations game, prepare to be very frustrated.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												They tried to copy the films and it didn't workCapcom Certainly Dropped and Egg with this, and I don't mean as a RE Title, forget about that and it is still a bad game, the films and the games should have been left as completely seperate entities.Despite the controversy and slating this got upon release when I saw it in the Summer sale for Six Bucks it was out of sheer morbid curiosity that I bought it.  The Portmanteau twist was something that I found interesting and if it had been done properly then it would have been amazing, but from what I understand Capcom blew the budget for this on Corperate Suits, Advisors and other assorted Professional Butt-Kissers who know nothing about actual Games or the fans that buy them.   Also while playing this the inconsistency of the graphics and a few other things gave me the sneeking impresion that corners had been cut and this had been rushed through so I did a little Due Dilligence which I found interesting. By far the largest RE game to date is the complete Revelations 2 with a Whopping Big 18 GB.  Coming second (surprisingly) is the HD Remaster of the Gamecube Remake at 17 GB.  However RE 6 comes Third at 16 GB, and that's after CAPCOM added more content because of the complaints,  so it would indeed seem that something had definately gone wrong in the production of this.  Let's face it these days most Independent Small Producers make product that hits around the 16 GB mark, but a Mega Companly such as CAPCOM can't produce better than this?!?!  Ultimately Capcom's clear distain of the fans is what wrecked a game that COULD have been a convincing Comeback for Resident Evil.First of all if you made it past the epic Train Wreck of an Intro Level without uninstalling it, either out of sheer frustration or because you genuinely thought it was broken, then well done because many have fallen here!   Ok that over and done with perhaps we can enjoy the actual game?  Nope, the PC version is still a complete stinker.....and I get the creepy, unshakable feeling that the Suits at Capcom were trying to punish us for not liking the change of direction they started in RE4 as I have not come across a game that does so much to deliberately sabotage itself  since  The Fabulous Wanda.  These awful game Mechanics don't happen by accident, someone has to plan and and code them, then they have to make it through testing and managment approval.  I really feel this may well be an act of spite from Capcom because we wouldn't jump through their Hoops and Like what they told us to Like.  Just a feeling...Visually it tries to be Epic, Glorious and Cinematic - it's such a shame that Two thirds of the time will be spent looking at the Keyboard!  If you thought RE5 has mega amounts of Quick Time then you ain't seen nothing yet.  The "JAKE" Level is almost exclusivly QT, and Visually Incomprehensable QT at that!  Instant Kill After Instant Kill after Instant Kill after Instant Kill makes the Two Hours completing this level this seem MUCH longer.  Hey Capcom...I didn't spend huge amounts of money on Top Quality components, sound systems and a HUGE TV so I can get neck Strain looking at my bloody Keyboard!!   I bought this equipment because I wanted an immersive experience and to get "Lost" in fantasy for a few hours.  Personally I HATE Quick Time because it destroys the experience just as certainly as that annoying idiot who Talks over the Film in the Cinema does.  This isn't Dragons Lair in 1985 for crying out loud, but that's what "Playing" RE6 feels like for the most part.  Give me Tank Controls any day over this.Ranting aside, and allowing for the Awful "Wesker JR" Level  what you have here are essentially Three versions of Mercinaries that try to share a common story but it's been done so badly that I just didn't care. The Chris level is a Buggy, Frustrating Clunk-Fest that REALLY showcases how bad the AI Partner system is (who just blocks your way from progressing and gets you killed)  and the Genius idea of having the game root you to the spot in crucial arears of battle while choosing the most unhelpful camera angle possible for you.  It also  unfathomably switches back to Tank Controls for the last boss fight which again are mostly uresponsive so good luck with that.  There is a resonably good Leon stage with a passable Ada stage so to make things slightly better save these for last.  Revelations 2 should have been the Real RE6, it is a much better game in all respects and I really do feel for all you whom bought RE6 at full price.Anyone else notice that they stole the music from the Ravenhearst Games?

												"QTE is my favorite part of the game", said no one ever!  Spoiler alert, this game features excessive amounts of QTE. There are also constant interruptions to game play and repetitive boss fights which further add to an already frustrating and disappointing experience! There was potential for something great here and it was squandered! Hopefully the devs pull their heads out of their asses and get it right next time...

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Overall, I think this game is just objectively poorly made and lazy. Though it's by no means good, it can be fun if you have someone to play it with and don't take it too seriously. I'll try to compile pros and cons as best I can: Cons: The controls are generally terrible. I've only played the PC version, but I've heard console controls are better, so you might wanna try that if you're looking to buy this. For example, the buttons to slide over cover are almost the exact same as the buttons to take cover. Unlike most games, where you can take cover and remain there until you choose to move, you have to hold a button the entire time you're in cover in addition to the buttons to fire. They also have a "quick shot" button combination that is the same as the button combination to fire normally, which is annoying.This game doesn't have the pause menu of RE 4 or the ability to assign items to the keyboard like RE 5. Instead, you have to manually scroll through every weapon in your inventory while everything in the known universe is attacking you. Good luck, son.This game does away with tank controls, which were a common complaint about older RE titles. This would be fine, expect for some completely baffling reason they didn't fix the problem that made them use tank controls in the first place. There are many scenes where the camera suddenly shifts angles from the usual third person to in front of you. If you weren't expecting this (and you won't be), you'll find yourself suddenly running the wrong away and immediately dying.The game will randomly switch into cutscene mode to show you your next objective, without actually pausing gameplay. The camera will return to your control just in time to see yourself get surround by the enemies that were closing in the whole time.Sometimes the game will enter a sort of cutscene mode when fighting bosses, during which they are invulnerable. The game will still allow you to fire on them during this, though, and it's hard to tell when you can actually hurt them and when you can't, since they hardly respond either way.Quick time events....quick time events everywhere! Dear lord.There are many moments where things can instantly kill you, and the only way to avoid them is to know they're coming in advance. This ain't a platformer, son.The above point wouldn't be so bad if the checkpoints for this game weren't completely terrible. Also, every chapter is very long, especially the first time you play through them. There is no manual saving and what few checkpoints they have are very unreliable.LOADING! Now, I'll try to be fair and say maybe the length of the loading screens is the fault of my computer/connection. However; the frequency of them is still ridiculous. Loading screen, play for 2 minutes, loading screen, watch cutscene, loading screen. JUST LET ME PLAYThe game can't figure out what genre it is. It's clear they tried to appease more old school RE fans with slower horror/puzzle based sections while still attracting newer players with action packed shooter segments. The end result is that both styles are very poorly done due to a lack of focus and polishing on either.Jake Muller Pros: The graphics are a thing of beauty. It's probably the only thing they worked hard on.They actually went the extra mile and gave every character their own individual melee moves.The plot is just as goofy and terrible as past RE games, just in a more action movie sense than b movie. Enjoy ripping the stupidity to shreds.GOOD STUFF! THANKS! NO WAY, NOT NOW! BEAUTIFUL! GOOD STUFF! GRATZIE! Annoy your friends by spamming commands!Stare at Leon and Helena's booties. MmhmmHas one of the best RE villians ever.All in all, don't by this game if you are expecting something fantastic. Don't buy it if you don't have someone fun to play it with. DEFINITELY don't buy it full price. However, if it's on sale and you just want something dumb to kill some time with, it's not that bad.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												JUST AWFUL.prosNOTHINGcons- settings UI. there is no texts but icons. so u must put on cursol to see what these icons are for.- camera. no slider to adjust FOV though its narrow. so u will get motion sickness in 1st ten minutes.- head bobbing. of course u can NEVER turn it off. surely u will puke after some hours like zombies.- NOT free mouse look. u will be limited sometimes even to watch ur back. - quick time events. even when u must just run, it demands QTE with stupid unreasonable keys. - unskippable cut scenes. if u died in QTE, u MUST see the same movie repeatedly until succeed.these are my 1st 10minutes playing review.but only within 10minutes, this game showed these fatal cons.and i must say about the 1st zombies battle was awful too.u will be surrounded by about 10 zombies in the night street filled with abandoned cars.but there is no enough lights. only u can do is to increase brightness with settings.so u must struggle in the darkness against zombies with annyoing backlights from carsthese shi-t backlighs never light up ur battlefield enough though idk why, they just blind ur eyes.maybe it means by the game director, "have fun my battle design in the ♥♥♥♥ing dark place, nerds".so i STOPPED playing this game after 10 minutes from start.and 1 more fun thing to tell u, this game does NOT have the button to quit.only the text appears in the title screen, "press any key to start, blah"so u MUST press alt + F4 to escape from this♥♥♥♥♥♥game's hell,but even these keys are recognized as "hitting keys" to start by this stupid client.of course ESC key NEVER works too in the title screen.i wanna give 100 thumbdowns for this game.i noticed now why this game was bundled in my Nvidia video card.if u expect the fun like Left 4 Dead for this game,u will be betrayed and depressed like a zombie soon.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2013
												This game is decent but not for a resident evil title, re6 is nothing like the classic resident evil titles which where what made the franchise what it is, all campaigns where made by a seperate team, which makes each campaign seem like a different game almost.  Leons campaign wasnt scary to me nothing about the game really is unless u get scared easily, also his campaign is littered with cinematics and quick time events, i noticed chris's campaign didnt have hardly any quick time events or cinematics just nonstop action in that one.i own re1 remake re2 re3 code veronica x now those are the best resident evil games ever, the music in those games was so awesome and atmopheric re6 music sucks, also the survival horror in the originals made it hella scary the fact u had very limited ammunition and had to run from the zombies and there where moments of tension everywhere where u where walking through areas where theres no enemies yet u still feel like they could pop out anywhere and kill u, the game put butterflys in my stomach i got so scared many times in those classics and i have many memories about those games.re6 is a decent action game, and i think the co-op is fun along with getting skill points for new skills, also the graphics are pretty nice and the cutscenes are well done, but the storyline isnt that great, although the resident evil series doesnt have the strongest storyline  the classics where alot more memorable and i prefer them, the puzzles in the classics where tough and when u did one on your own without looking it up on the computer it makes u feel like u accomplished something in which makes u not forget that moment and what it took to beat the game.If i was to make a resident evil game, i would keep the tank controls, it makes the game harder and your character feels less like a badass doing rolls and owning the zombies instead of being overwelmed and running, i would change to 3d backgrounds like u did in this game but with the classic camera angles. i saw a few of classic camera angles in re6 on leons campaign in a few areas and liked them.ADD BACK THE SURVIVAL HORROR!I dont want a shooting gallery where i never run outta ammo and the zombies just keep coming to where i expect this and am never scared, supplies should be limited and shouldnt fall from zombies when they die but should be scattered across the map, i want to feel the terror of walking not expecting zombies to pop out.Also the item box returns and the ink ribbon...CAPCOM: sry didnt quite impress me with this game.but i loved re1 remake on gamecube that is how its done and that game was hella scary and was a remake done right, if u would just go back to this style i would be jumping to buy the next resident evil instead of sluggishly thinking about getting it.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2013
												It has rough controls, sudden death QTEs that appear out of nowhere, a camera that forces the player to look at a direction for cinematic purposes, atrocious inventory system, no weapon upgrade system, alternate costumes are unusable in the campaign, and the inability to pause even in offline mode♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the hell out of me. The story is typical anime-style with Michael Bay explosions every few minutes (I felt sorry for these characters because they can't rest and encounters one bad scenario after the another). This is not survival horror.  On the plus side, this game is very well produced, well-acted, attractive-looking, and engine performance is well optimized for the PC.After all those negatives, I still like RE6. I like the game. Yes, as a fan and followed the numbered REs, I'm biased. If you're a fan and wants to see more of the characters you loved and hated since RE1, this game is not to be missed.7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Resident evil... it has changed quite a lot since that first time we stepped inside that mansion. There are a lot of mixed reviews regarding RE6 - what did I think? I actually liked it, and this comes from an all-time fan of the franchise. I guess you have to look at this game not as a survival horror but as an action game with old characters. The campaign is really fun and very hard due to the new controls but at the end satisfying and isn't that what we look for in a video game? Having fun but getting challenged? Now I'm not saying that this is the best RE game (I think that title belongs to RE4), but it is a good direction to take, maybe in the future we might get to see these action-based controls in a more suvival horrorish kind of game, who knows, that's all up to capcom. But you know what I would criticize? I think it's time for a change of characters - I liked Sherry and Jake as new protagonists, but seriously it's time for Chris to hang the towel, he's been on RE1, RE: Code Veronica, RE5, RE6 and Revelations (the ones that I know), so there's not much character development left.
